questions.text: Feeding is done through the given method. Which of the following is not a complication of this:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aspiration pneumonia

 

The given image shows a central line used for total parenteral nutrition (TPN). Common complications of TPN and central line insertion include pneumothorax, osteoporosis, and refeeding syndrome. Aspiration pneumonia is a complication more associated with enteral feeding rather than parenteral feeding.

 

Aspiration pneumonia is commonly seen when a patient has issues with swallowing or is fed through tubes inserted into the gastrointestinal tract. It occurs when food, liquid, or saliva is inhaled into the lungs, leading to infection. The patient can be placed in a semi-recumbent position during feeding to avoid this.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Refeeding syndrome: This is a serious metabolic complication of both parenteral and enteral feeding, especially in severely malnourished patients. It is caused by the sudden shift in electrolytes, particularly phosphate, when refeeding is initiated. It can lead to dangerous shifts in fluids and electrolytes.

 

Option B. Osteoporosis: This is a long-term complication of total parenteral nutrition. The lack of normal digestive processing may lead to deficiencies in calcium and phosphate, which, along with other factors, contribute to decreased bone density, resulting in osteoporosis.

 

Option C. Pneumothorax: This is a common complication during the insertion of a central line, particularly when the subclavian vein is used. It occurs when the lung is punctured, allowing air to collect in the pleural space. It can be managed by inserting a chest drain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary complications of total parenteral nutrition (TPN) through a central line include pneumothorax (during insertion), refeeding syndrome (a metabolic disorder), and osteoporosis (from long-term use). Aspiration pneumonia is associated more with enteral feeding rather than parenteral feeding.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with complaints of bone pain and abdominal cramps with persistent low mood. Which of the following would be the best investigation for a definitive diagnosis? (AIIMS 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sestamibi scan

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features of 40-year-old woman with bone pain and abdominal cramps along with persistent low mood is suggestive of hypercalcemia, which could be due to primary Hyperparathyroidism.

 

IOC for parathyroid adenoma: Tc99-Sestamibi scan

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): While useful for detailed soft tissue imaging, MRI is not the first choice for detecting parathyroid adenomas.

 

Option C. Ultrasonogram: Can be used to locate parathyroid adenomas but has limitations in sensitivity and specificity compared to the Sestamibi scan.

 

Option D. CT scan (Computed Tomography): Provides good anatomic detail but is less specific than the Sestamibi scan for parathyroid adenomas and is not the primary diagnostic tool for suspected hyperparathyroidism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a definitive diagnosis in patients presenting with symptoms indicative of hypercalcemia and suspected primary hyperparathyroidism, a Sestamibi scan is the investigation of choice due to its specificity and ability to perform detailed scintigraphic imaging.

choices.text: Do a routine episiotomy
Manual support to the perineum to maintain flexion of the head
Never give warm compress to the perineum
Perform labor in lithotomy position

questions.text: Which of the following is part of the WHO recommendations for managing the second stage of labor? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Manual support to the perineum to maintain flexion of the head

 

The WHO guidelines for the management of the second stage of labor recommend manual support to the perineum and controlled delivery of the fetal head. This method, also known as guarding the perineum, reduces the risk of perineal trauma by preventing rapid delivery of the head. Gentle downward pressure is applied on the occiput to control the speed of delivery, and once the occiput is born, the rest of the head is delivered with gentle assistance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Do a routine episiotomy: Routine episiotomy is not recommended by the WHO. Episiotomies should be reserved for specific conditions, such as shoulder dystocia, breech deliveries, or fetal macrosomia. The procedure is not to be routinely performed because it can increase the risk of unnecessary trauma.

 

Option C. Never give warm compress to the perineum: This statement is incorrect. The WHO suggests using warm compresses to the perineum during labor to reduce the risk of perineal tears and improve maternal comfort during the delivery.

 

Option D. Perform labor in lithotomy position: While the lithotomy position is commonly used, the WHO recommends allowing the woman to choose her position during labor, including upright positions (such as squatting or standing), which are associated with improved outcomes and less perineal trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO recommends manual support of the perineum during the second stage of labor to reduce perineal trauma. Routine episiotomies should be avoided unless clinically necessary.

questions.text: All are reduced in Iron Deficiency Anemia except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) TIBC

 

In Iron Deficiency Anemia, Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC) is increased in order to compensate to the deficient state.

 

Iron deficiency anemia –

 

Progressive depletion of iron reserves first lowers serum iron and transferrin saturation levels without producing anemia. In this early stage there is increased erythroid activity in the bone marrow.

 

Anemia appears only when iron stores are completely depleted and is accompanied by low serum iron, ferritin, and transferrin saturation levels.

 

The serum iron and ferritin are low, and the total plasma iron-binding capacity (reflecting elevated transferrin levels) is high. Low serum iron with increased iron-binding capacity results in a reduction of transferrin saturation to below 15%. Reduced iron stores inhibit hepcidin synthesis, and its serum levels fall and this in turn facilitates iron absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferritin: Ferritin is an intracellular protein that stores iron and releases it in a controlled fashion. In IDA, ferritin levels drop as iron stores are exhausted.

 

Option C. Iron: Serum Iron reflects the amount of circulating iron bound to transferrin. In IDA, serum iron levels are reduced because iron stores are depleted.

 

Option D. Transferrin Saturation: This is the percentage of transferrin that is saturated with iron. In IDA, it is reduced because there is less iron available to bind to transferrin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DDs of microcytic anemia:-

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 1231-1234

questions.text:
What is the correct sequence of management in a patient who presents to the casualty with an RTA (Road Traffic Accident)? (INICET NOV 2022) 

 

  1. Cervical spine stabilization
  2. Intubation
  3. IV cannulation
  4. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

The correct sequence of management in a patient who presents to the casualty with an RTA is Option B. Cervical spine stabilization, Intubation, IV cannulation, and CECT, as per the ABCDE protocol in trauma management.

 

According to the Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) protocol, the management follows the primary survey with the following steps:

 

  1. Cervical spine stabilization: Always prioritize stabilizing the cervical spine in trauma patients, especially in cases where spinal injury is suspected.
  2. Intubation: After airway management, securing the airway via intubation is crucial to ensure oxygenation and prevent aspiration.
  3. IV cannulation: Establish intravenous access for fluid resuscitation and medication administration.
  4. CECT: Imaging, such as contrast-enhanced CT (CECT), is performed once the patient is stabilized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1, 3, 2, 4: While cervical spine stabilization is correctly prioritized, IV cannulation should not occur before securing the airway with intubation. Airway management is always the top priority after stabilizing the cervical spine.

 

Option C. 2, 1, 3, 4: Intubation before cervical spine stabilization is incorrect because spinal injury protection takes precedence in trauma patients. Airway management should follow after ensuring the spine is stabilized.

 

Option D. 2, 1, 4, 3: Intubation before cervical spine stabilization is incorrect, and performing CECT before IV cannulation would delay critical fluid resuscitation and medication access.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence in the primary survey of trauma management includes cervical spine stabilization, airway protection (intubation), intravenous access, and imaging (CECT) to assess injuries. Following the ATLS protocol ensures patient stabilization and appropriate treatment priorities.

questions.text: Which of the following causes aplastic crisis in hereditary spherocytosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Parvovirus

 

ParvoVirus-B19 infects erythroid progenitor cells and inhibits erythropoiesis, leading to acute erythroblastopenia and reticulocytopenia. The bone marrow in patients with transient aplastic crisis is characterized by an absence of maturing erythroid precursors and presence of giant pro-normoblasts. Although giant pro-normoblasts are suggestive of parvovirus B19 infection, they are not diagnostic of the disease. Aplastic crisis in a patient with hereditary spherocytosis is because of pancytopenia accompanied with a marked decrease in reticulocytes. Bone marrow aspiration may not be routinely required when viral infection-induced aplastic crisis is highly suspected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Poxvirus: Poxviruses are not associated with causing aplastic crisis.

 

Option B. Epstein-Barr virus: While Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) can cause hematologic abnormalities, it is not typically associated with causing aplastic crisis in hereditary spherocytosis.

 

Option C. Adenovirus: Adenovirus infections are common but are not known to cause aplastic crisis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 is the causative agent for aplastic crisis in patients with hereditary spherocytosis. It infects erythroid progenitor cells, inhibiting erythropoiesis and leading to a significant decrease in reticulocytes, causing acute erythroblastopenia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old postmenopausal woman comes with a history of Colles’ fracture 6 months ago. Her DEXA scan reveals T score of -2.5. What is the next best step?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alendronate

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • Bone mineral density is measured by DEXA scan (65 years onwards).
  • Normal Ca2+, PO‑4, ALP
  • Hemiplegic – Humerus maximum loss of bone mineral density.

 

 

  • Etiology:

 

 

  • Radiological Investigation: 
    • Quantitative CT is a newer imaging technique that can be used to detect osteoporosis.
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae

 

  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.

 

  • Treatment:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate
       
  • Alendronate:
    • Alendronate is approved for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis, steroid-induced osteoporosis, and male osteoporosis.
    • Alendronate belongs to the class of bisphosphonate medications, which aids in the prevention of bone resorption and the promotion of bone density, making it a valuable treatment for osteoporosis.
    • Alendronate is an option for maintaining or increasing bone mass, whereas risedronate is preferred in men with osteoporosis.
    • It inhibit bone resorption at rates 1000 times greater than the effect on bone formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium and Vitamin D. They are given along with the bisphosphonates but are not the only treatment choice. Calcium is given at a dose of 1500 mg/day. Vitamin D is given at the dose of 400-800 IU per day. Initially, Vit. D deficient patients are treated with active metabolite 1,25, dihydroxy Vit D3 (short half-life 4 hours and expensive) then changing over to longer lasting and less expensive Vit D2 or D3 (t ½ up to 2½ months).

 

Option B. Hormone replacement therapy. The mainstay of bone loss prevention in postmenopausal osteoporosis is estrogen treatment. Daily dose of 0.625 mg of conjugated estrogen in combination with progestins are recommended. Progestin is essential (even though it has no independent effect on bone) to reduce the risk of developing endometrial cancer (due to estrogen).

 

Option D. Repeat DEXA scan after 6 months. The DEXA scan is repeated after 6 months to 1 year after starting of the drug treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alendronate, a drug of class of bisphosphonates is the drug of choice for the treatment of osteoporosis.

questions.text: Which Biochemical method is exploited for monoclonal antibody production by hybridoma technique?  (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Purine salvage pathway

 

Hybridoma technology → common methods used to produce monoclonal antibodies

 

In this process, antibody-producing B-lymphocytes are isolated from mice after immunizing the mice with specific antigen and are fused with immortal myeloma cell lines to form hybrid cells, called hybridoma cell lines.

 

 

  • Even the most efficient fusion method will give only 1 to 2% of fused and viable hybridoma cells.
  • Hybridoma selection involve screening of the fused cells from the unfused cells. It is done using HAT media (a selection media).
  • HAT medium contains Hypoxanthine-Aminopterin-Thymidine. The trick is that Aminopterin inhibits DHFR. So, it inhibits de-novo purine synthesis. Inhibition of DHFR also inhibits conversion of dUMP to dTMP.
  • Salvage pathway will occur, but only in B-cells, not myeloma cells. Myeloma cells are deficient in HGPRT .
  • Hypoxanthine and deoxythymidine allow cells with functional hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) genes to survive through salvage pathways.
  • Due to a limited life span, unfused B cells perish within a few days.
  • Unfused malignant neoplastic cells die as a result of the lack of HGPRT gene
  • Therefore, the remaining viable cells left in the media are the hybrid cells; these hybrid cells have the ability to grow and divide on HAT media because they have functional HGPRT gene from B lymphocytes

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycolytic pathway: This pathway is involved in the breakdown of glucose to pyruvate for energy production and is not specifically exploited in hybridoma technology for monoclonal antibody production.

 

Option B. Pentose Phosphate pathway: This pathway generates NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate for nucleotide synthesis but is not the key pathway exploited in the hybridoma technique.

 

Option C. Kreb’s cycle: This cycle is part of cellular respiration and energy production but is not directly involved in the selection process of hybridoma cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The purine salvage pathway is critical in hybridoma technology for monoclonal antibody production, enabling the selection of viable hybridoma cells in HAT medium.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Neonates who are asymptomatic at birth have a lesser risk of later sequelae.
  2. 20-40% are symptomatic at birth.
  3. In developing countries, the rate of transmission of CMV infection to the infant is more common from primary maternal infection than reactivation.
  4. Diagnosis by urine specimen at 4 weeks of age
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3

 

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a common congenital infection, and understanding the nuances of its transmission, diagnosis, and clinical implications is important.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Congenital CMV Infection:
    • Transmission: Congenital CMV infection can occur from either primary maternal infection (which is when the mother is infected with CMV for the first time during pregnancy) or from reactivation of a prior CMV infection in the mother. The risk of transmission to the fetus is significantly higher in cases of primary maternal infection (around 30%) compared to reactivation (about 1-2%). In developing countries, the prevalence of CMV reactivation is higher, but primary infection remains the more significant source of transmission to the fetus.
    • Asymptomatic vs. Symptomatic: The majority of neonates with congenital CMV are asymptomatic at birth, and these asymptomatic infants have a lower risk of developing long-term sequelae such as sensorineural hearing loss compared to those who are symptomatic at birth.
    • Clinical Presentation: About 10% of neonates with congenital CMV infection are symptomatic at birth. Symptoms can include hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rash, jaundice, chorioretinitis, microcephaly, and thrombocytopenia. These symptoms are associated with a higher risk of long-term complications.
    • Diagnosis: CMV infection can be diagnosed by detecting the virus in urine, saliva, or blood within the first three weeks of life. Diagnosis at four weeks, as mentioned in option 4, is less likely to be reliable because it may represent postnatal infection rather than congenital infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B (1, 2): The percentage of neonates symptomatic at birth is around 10%, not 20-40%.

 

Option C (2, 4): The diagnosis by urine specimen at four weeks is not ideal, and the percentage of symptomatic neonates at birth is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonates who are asymptomatic at birth from congenital CMV infection have a lower risk of long-term sequelae, and transmission is more common from primary maternal infection than from reactivation, especially in developing countries.

choices.text: Metabolic alkalosis with high anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with high anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap
Metabolic alkalosis with normal anion gap

questions.text: Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities is seen in methanol intoxication? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metabolic acidosis with high anion gap

 

Methanol intoxication leads to metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap & high osmolal gap. Methanol is metabolized in the body to formic acid, which is a strong acid. The accumulation of formic acid in the bloodstream results in an increase in hydrogen ion concentration, leading to acidosis. The high anion gap indicates that there are unmeasured anions (such as formate) contributing to the acidosis. In addition to causing a high anion gap, methanol intoxication also leads to a high osmolal gap, which is another diagnostic clue in cases of toxic alcohol ingestion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic alkalosis with high anion gap: This statement is incorrect because methanol intoxication does not cause alkalosis. Instead, it causes acidosis due to the production of formic acid.

 

Option C. Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap: This statement is incorrect because the acidosis caused by methanol intoxication is characterized by a high anion gap due to the accumulation of formate, a byproduct of methanol metabolism.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis with normal anion gap: This statement is incorrect because methanol intoxication leads to acidosis, not alkalosis, and the anion gap is elevated, not normal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methanol intoxication causes metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap due to the accumulation of formic acid.

choices.text: Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, HBV, Injectable Polio
Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Haemophilus influenza B, Pneumococcal vaccine

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic for her first round of vaccinations. The mother is anxious and wants to ensure her child receives all the necessary immunizations. You explain that one of the shots the child will receive is the Pentavalent vaccine, which combines five different immunizations into a single injection. Which of the following immunizations are combined in the Pentavalent vaccine? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Diphtheria, Tetanus, HBV, Haemophilus influenza B, Pertussis

 

  • Pentavalent vaccine consists of five vaccines - Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Hepatitis B and Haemophilus Influenzae Type B (Hib).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

NEW National Immunization Schedule (NIS) 2023-24

questions.text: The given ECG depicts which of the following conditions:  (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ventricular bigeminy

 

Premature ventricular complex (PVCs)- Have following features

 

  • Broad QRS complex (>120ms) with abnormal morphology
  • Premature- i.e., occurs earlier than would be expected for the next sinus impulse
  • Discordant ST segment and T wave changes.
  • Usually followed by a full compensatory pause

 

PVCs often occur in repeating pattern: bigeminy, trigeminy, quadrigeminy

 

Couplet: 2 consecutive PVCs is known as couplet

 

Triplet: 3 consecutive PVCs is known as triplet

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PSVT (Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia): This condition would show a fast, regular heart rate with narrow QRS complexes; not observed here.

 

Option C. P pulmonale: This involves peaked P waves seen in leads II, III, and aVF, typically due to right atrial enlargement; not evident in this ECG.

 

Option D. Re-entrant atrial fibrillation: Would show an irregularly irregular rhythm without consistent P waves; this is not present in the ECG provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ventricular bigeminy is identified by the presence of alternating normal sinus beats and PVCs, each PVC typically followed by a compensatory pause, creating a repeating pattern of one normal beat followed by one abnormal beat.

questions.text: In fetal alcohol syndrome, which of the following is not seen? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Macrocephaly

 

  • Fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) is associated with microcephaly, not macrocephaly.

 

 

Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) is a condition that arises from excessive alcohol exposure during pregnancy, which leads to a range of developmental abnormalities. FAS is characterized by several key features, including facial anomalies, central nervous system (CNS) dysfunction, and growth deficiencies.

 

  • Facial Anomalies: The classic facial features of FAS include small eye openings (narrow palpebral fissures), a smooth philtrum (the area between the nose and upper lip), and a thin upper lip. Other features may include epicanthic folds, a flattened nasal bridge, a short nose, low-set and unparallel ears, and midfacial hypoplasia.
  • CNS Dysfunction: This includes microcephaly (small head size), mental retardation, and neurobehavioral abnormalities such as attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). The presence of microcephaly is a common finding in FAS, reflecting the overall poor brain growth and development.
  • Thinning of Corpus Callosum: FAS can lead to structural brain abnormalities such as thinning or complete agenesis of the corpus callosum, which is the band of nerve fibers that connects the two hemispheres of the brain.
  • Holoprosencephaly: This is a severe brain malformation where the forebrain fails to divide into two hemispheres, which can be seen in more severe cases of FAS.

 

Macrocephaly (enlarged head size) is not a feature of FAS. On the contrary, FAS is typically associated with microcephaly, reflecting the impaired brain growth caused by alcohol exposure during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thinning of corpus callosum: This is a known CNS abnormality in FAS, reflecting the significant impact of alcohol on brain structure and development.

 

Option B. Microcephaly: One of the hallmark features of FAS, microcephaly indicates reduced brain size and development, commonly seen in affected infants.

 

Option C. Holoprosencephaly: This severe brain malformation can occur in the context of FAS, particularly in cases where the alcohol exposure has profoundly disrupted early brain development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) is associated with microcephaly and other CNS abnormalities, but macrocephaly is not a feature of this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most specific marker for alcoholism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GGT

 

Gamma Glutamyl Transferase (GGT) is the most specific marker for alcoholism among the options provided. Elevated GGT levels, particularly when disproportionate to other liver enzymes such as ALT and ALP, are commonly associated with alcohol abuse or alcoholic liver disease. GGT has a sensitivity and specificity greater than 60% for detecting heavy alcohol use, especially when levels exceed 35 U/L. Combining GGT with carbohydrate-deficient transferrin (CDT) measurements can increase diagnostic accuracy for chronic alcohol consumption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ALT (Alanine Aminotransferase):  ALT is typically elevated in acute hepatocellular injuries such as hepatitis. As ALT is predominantly located in the liver, it serves as a specific marker for liver cell injury but not specifically for alcohol use. A high AST/ALT ratio (greater than 2:1) can suggest alcoholic liver disease, but ALT levels are often normal in these cases.

 

Option C. ALP (Alkaline Phosphatase):  ALP elevation is more commonly seen in cholestasis (bile flow obstruction) and in physiological states like rapid bone growth or pregnancy. It is not a specific marker for alcohol use.

 

Option D. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase):  LDH is a non-specific marker that can be elevated in various conditions, including liver disease, hemolysis, and tissue breakdown, but it does not specifically indicate alcoholism.

 

Educational Objective:


GGT is the most specific marker for chronic alcohol use and alcoholic liver disease, especially when levels are elevated independently or out of proportion to other liver enzymes.

questions.text: Dr. Mehta, Public health expert who works extensively with the National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP) in India. In a meeting with local health workers in 2017, he has shared the data and progress made in controlling leprosy. He mentions the crucial statistic of the Annual New Case Detection Rate (ANCDR) as of March 31, 2016, to give a snapshot of the magnitude of new leprosy cases detected. This rate helps in understanding the effectiveness of ongoing programs and strategies. What value did Dr. Mehta share as the ANCDR for leprosy for that specific year? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 9.7/1 lakh population

 

During the 2015-2016 period, India recorded an annual new case detection rate (ANCDR) for leprosy at 9.7 per 100,000 people.

 

Annual New Case Detection Rate (ANCDR):

 

  • An important Indicator being used under the National Leprosy Eradication Program 
  • Indicator is calculated at the end of March every year, wherein New Cases detected during the period April (Previous Calendar year) and March (current year) is used
  • ANCDR - 2015-16: 9.71 per 100,000 population
  • ANCDR - 2021-22: 5.52 per 100,000 population

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ANCDR is a pivotal indicator in disease surveillance and control programs, helping public health officials and stakeholders understand the scale of new cases and the impact of interventions.
  • For leprosy in India, maintaining a keen understanding of this rate is essential for achieving the goals of the National Leprosy Eradication Programme.

questions.text: Device shown in the image is used for which purpose?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prevent transfusion-related reactions

 

The device shown in the image is a leukoreduction filter. It is specifically designed to filter out donor white blood cells (WBCs) from blood products. The removal of these WBCs helps to reduce the risk of transfusion-related reactions, which are commonly associated with the presence of WBC microaggregates in blood components. Leukoreduction is most effective when performed before the storage of blood, as it minimizes the activation and accumulation of WBCs during storage.

 

Key benefits of leukoreduction include:

 

  1. Reduced risk of sensitization to HLA antigens: This is critical for patients who may require organ or bone marrow transplants, as it helps prevent the development of antibodies against HLA, which could lead to platelet refractoriness.
  2. Prevention of Febrile Non-Hemolytic Transfusion Reactions (FNHTR): These are common adverse reactions characterized by fever and chills, which occur due to the recipient's immune response to donor WBCs.
  3. Lowered risk of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) transmission: CMV has an affinity for monocytes and macrophages, both of which are types of WBCs. By reducing the WBC count, the risk of CMV transmission is indirectly decreased. However, it is important to note that the primary purpose of leukoreduction is not to prevent CMV transmission but rather to reduce transfusion-related reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prevent viral infections: This option is incorrect. While leukoreduction can reduce the risk of certain viral infections, such as CMV (which is linked to WBCs), this is an indirect and accidental benefit. The primary purpose of the filter is not to prevent viral infections.

 

Option C. Prevent infections: This is incorrect. The leukoreduction filter does not directly prevent infections. It specifically targets donor WBCs to minimize transfusion reactions. Preventing infections, in general, requires sterile techniques and other infection control measures.

 

Option D. All of the above: This option is incorrect. Although the leukoreduction filter has some incidental benefits, such as reducing the risk of CMV transmission, its main and most efficient purpose is to prevent transfusion-related reactions by removing WBCs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary purpose of a leukoreduction filter is to prevent transfusion-related reactions by removing donor WBCs.

choices.text: Bar and boot plaster

questions.text: A 75-year-old patient suffers with extracapsular femoral neck fracture. What would be the most appropriate management option for her management?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intramedullary nailing

 

INTRAMEDULLARY NAILING

 

  • Intramedullary Nailing is a surgical technique used to stabilize fractures by inserting a metal rod (nail) into the medullary canal of the bone.
  • Mechanism: The nail is inserted into the central canal of the femur and fixed with screws at the ends to stabilize the fracture.

 

 

  • It is generally used for femoral shaft fractures but can be applied to extracapsular femoral neck fractures in elderly.
  • Indications: Intramedullary nailing is effective for stabilizing long bone fractures and can be used for femoral neck fractures if the fracture pattern and bone quality are suitable.
  • Complications: There is a risk of complications including infection, nonunion, and poor functional outcomes if not done properly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Russell’s Traction: Russell’s Traction is a type of skeletal traction used to align and stabilize fractures, particularly in the lower extremities. This traction method involves applying a pulling force to the limb through a system of pulleys and weights. It can help in aligning fractured bones and reducing pain by immobilizing the affected limb. For elderly patients with extracapsular femoral neck fractures, Russell’s traction is less preferred due to delayed recovery as the traction does not allow early weight-bearing or mobility, which is crucial for elderly patients to prevent complications like pressure sores and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The immobilization provided by traction alone might not adequately stabilize the fracture, leading to a higher risk of nonunion or malunion. Prolonged use of traction can lead to muscle atrophy and joint stiffness.

 

 

Option B. Bar and Boot Plaster: Bar and Boot Plaster is a type of external immobilization used for fractures, particularly in the lower limb. This involves applying a plaster cast to immobilize the fractured limb, often including a bar and boot to provide additional support and alignment. It is used for fractures where conservative management is appropriate, particularly in pediatric or less complex cases. For extracapsular femoral neck fractures in elderly patients, this method is generally not preferred due to inadequate stabilization. Prolonged immobilization can lead to complications such as muscle atrophy, joint stiffness, and pressure sores, especially in elderly patients who are already at high risk for these issues.

 

 

Option D. Hemiarthroplasty: Hemiarthroplasty involves replacing the damaged femoral head with a prosthetic component while leaving the acetabulum intact. It is often used to address both the fracture and any pre-existing joint degeneration. Hemiarthroplasty is often preferred for intracapsular femoral neck fractures in elderly patients due to immediate stability provided to the hip joint and allowance for earlier weight-bearing and mobility, which is crucial for elderly patients to reduce the risk of complications from prolonged immobility. The prosthesis can alleviate pain and improve functional outcomes compared to conservative management methods. The procedure has risks such as dislocation, infection, and prosthesis failure, but it generally provides better outcomes in terms of mobility and quality of life for elderly patients compared to non-surgical methods.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intramedullary nailing, while useful for certain types of fractures, is generally the first choice for extracapsular femoral neck fractures in elderly patients due to the risks and potential complications associated with the procedure.
  • Cephalomedullary nailing is done in such cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with severe back pain, vomiting, and hypotension. CT findings are given below. What is the diagnosis?(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Renal angiomyolipoma

 

Explanation:

 

The CT image shows a left renal lesion with negative /low attenuation (black in color) that indicate fatty tissue. This is consistent with renal angiomyolipoma. Clinical findings of severe back pain, vomiting, and hypotension and hematoma around the renal mass are suggestive of rupture. This is known as Wunderlich syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal cysts are homogeneous hypodense lesions.

 

Option B. Renal cell carcinoma will appear heterogeneous and hypervacular with areas of necrosis.

 

Option C. Para pelvic cyst are  simple renal cysts that plunge into the renal sinus from the adjacent renal parenchyma. A parapelvic cyst at times may cause compression of the pelvicalyceal system resulting in hydronephrosis. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal angiomyolipoma is typically composed of fat, muscle, and blood vessels and appears as a low-attenuation mass on CT scans. When associated with symptoms like severe pain and hypotension, it raises concerns for potential hemorrhage or rupture, emphasizing the need for prompt evaluation and management.

choices.text: The trial investigated NSCLC treatment using a combination of pembrolizumab and chemotherapy.
The trial focused solely on the use of pembrolizumab for treating NSCLC.
The study explored the efficacy of combining nivolumab and chemotherapy for NSCLC.
The trial looked at nivolumab as a treatment option for NSCLC.

questions.text: An oncologist is discussing with a colleague about the latest evidence-based approaches to treating non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The KEYNOTE-189 trial comes up in their conversation. Which of the following accurately describes the focus of the KEYNOTE-189 trial? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The trial investigated NSCLC treatment using a combination of pembrolizumab and chemotherapy.

 

The KEYNOTE trials are a series of clinical studies investigating the use of pembrolizumab, an immune checkpoint inhibitor, in various types of cancer. Pembrolizumab targets the PD-1 receptor, thereby enabling the immune system to better recognize and attack cancer cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The trial focused solely on the use of pembrolizumab for treating NSCLC: This is incorrect. The KEYNOTE-189 trial investigated pembrolizumab in combination with chemotherapy, not as a monotherapy.

 

Option C. The study explored the efficacy of combining nivolumab and chemotherapy for NSCLC: This is incorrect. The KEYNOTE-189 trial did not involve nivolumab; it focused on pembrolizumab in combination with chemotherapy.

 

Option D. The trial looked at nivolumab as a treatment option for NSCLC: This is incorrect. The KEYNOTE-189 trial was centered on pembrolizumab, not nivolumab.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is the color of vacutainer containing sodium fluoride as a content? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Grey

 

The grey-colored vacutainer contains sodium fluoride as an anticoagulant. Sodium fluoride acts by inhibiting glycolysis, which is the breakdown of glucose by enzymes, releasing energy and pyruvic acid. By inhibiting this process, sodium fluoride preserves the glucose levels in the blood sample, making it ideal for the estimation of blood glucose and alcohol levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Red: Red tubes typically do not contain an anticoagulant and are used for serum tests where the blood is allowed to clot before centrifugation.

 

Option C. Blue: Blue tubes usually contain sodium citrate as an anticoagulant, used primarily for coagulation studies such as PT and PTT.

 

Option D. Yellow: Yellow tubes may contain ACD (acid-citrate-dextrose) or SPS (sodium polyanethol sulfonate), used for blood cultures or blood bank studies.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Weakly basic drugs
Weakly acidic drugs

questions.text: Alkalinization of urine will be helpful in the treatment of poisoning due to?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Weakly acidic drugs

 

Alkalinization of urine is effective in treating overdoses of weakly acidic drugs. By increasing the pH of the urine, it promotes the ionization of these drugs. Ionized drugs are less likely to be reabsorbed in the kidney tubules and are more readily excreted. This principle is particularly applied in cases of aspirin (salicylate) poisoning.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Weakly basic drugs: Urinary alkalinization is not typically used for weakly basic drugs. Basic drugs are more likely to be reabsorbed in an alkaline environment, making this approach counterproductive.

 

Option B. Strong acids: Strong acids are not significantly affected by urinary pH, so alkalinization would not be particularly beneficial.

 

Option C. Strong bases: Similar to strong acids, strong bases are not significantly impacted by changes in urinary pH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkalinization of urine is an effective strategy to enhance the excretion of weakly acidic drugs by increasing their ionization and reducing their reabsorption in the renal tubules, thus promoting their elimination from the body. This method is particularly useful in cases of poisoning with weak acids, such as aspirin (salicylates).

choices.text: For smoothening of edges in amputation surgery
To remove fibrous tissue from non-union site

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is used for:(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Used as a bone nibbler

 

BONE NIBBLER

 

  • Bone Nibbler/Bone Rongeurs are like pliers with a heavy, pointed jaw.
  • With their heavy construction, bone nibblers are used for gnawing holes in bones during Orthopedic surgery.
  • The scoop-shaped tip of the rongeur is used for gouging the bone.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. For cutting ribs in thoracic surgery. Rib Shears are surgical instruments used in cardiothoracic surgeries to cut bones, especially ribs. They absorb the shock of the cut and provide an atraumatic experience. 

 

 

Option B. For smoothening of edges in amputation surgery. Putti Bone Rasp is used for orthopedic surgeries that require mild reshaping and handling of bones. It is a double-ended instrument used for debriding and smoothing the bone edges after the amputation surgery.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

The image shown in the question is of a bone nibbler which is used to gnaw holes in the bones during the surgery.

questions.text: A patient presented to the casualty with signs of dehydration due to severe vomiting. The intern gave the patient a parenteral medication, following which the patient developed grimacing and abnormal posturing. What could have been the inciting drug for this reaction? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Metoclopramide

 

Metoclopramide is an anti-emetic that acts by blocking the D2 receptors. It can cross the blood brain barrier and can lead to Dopaminergic blockade in the various parts of the brain leading to Acute dystonia, drowsiness, abnormal posturing, Parkinsonism etc.

 

Domperidone is also a D2 Receptor blocker, but cannot cross the BBB, therefore it does not produce such side effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug that does not typically cause extrapyramidal side effects. It is used to reduce salivation and bronchial secretions and to treat bradycardia.

 

Option B. Ranitidine: Ranitidine is an H2 receptor antagonist used to reduce stomach acid production. It does not have significant central nervous system effects or cause extrapyramidal symptoms.

 

Option D. Domperidone: Domperidone is also a dopamine D2 receptor blocker used as an anti-emetic. However, it does not cross the blood-brain barrier effectively and therefore does not typically cause central nervous system side effects like metoclopramide.

 

Educational Objective

 

Metoclopramide, an anti-emetic that blocks D2 receptors and crosses the blood-brain barrier, can cause extrapyramidal side effects such as acute dystonia, drowsiness, abnormal posturing, and Parkinsonism-like symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanism in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is mainly responsible for the resorption of divalent ions? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Paracellular Transport

 

Paracellular Transport in the thick ascending limb of loop of Henle is responsible for the resorption of divalent ions such as, calcium, magnesium, etc.

 

The sodium-potassium ATPase pump in the basolateral cell membrane maintains a low intracellular sodium concentration and a negative electrical potential in the cell.

 

The 1-sodium, 2-chloride, 1-potassium co-transporter in the luminal membrane transports these three ions from the tubular lumen into the cells, using the potential energy released by diffusion of sodium down an electrochemical gradient into the cells.

 

Sodium is also transported into the tubular cell by sodium-hydrogen counter-transport.

 

The positive charge (+8 mV) due to slight back leak of potassium ions into the lumen of the tubular lumen relative to the interstitial fluid forces cations such as Mg++ and Ca++ to diffuse from the lumen to the interstitial fluid via the paracellular pathway.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary active: Incorrect. This involves direct use of ATP for ion transport, not the main mechanism for divalent ion resorption in the thick ascending limb.

 

Option B. Secondary Active: Incorrect. While secondary active transport is important for moving ions, it is not the primary mechanism for divalent ion resorption here.

 

Option D. Transcellular Transport: Incorrect. Transcellular transport involves movement through the cell, whereas divalent ion resorption primarily occurs via the paracellular pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paracellular transport in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is the main mechanism responsible for the resorption of divalent ions such as calcium and magnesium, driven by the positive luminal charge and facilitated by the sodium-potassium ATPase pump and co-transporters.

choices.text: Inside the membrane
At the C-terminal
At the N-terminal
Both inside the membrane and at C- terminal

questions.text: The signaling sequence in a type 2 membrane protein with N-terminal facing cytoplasm is located in?(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inside the membrane

 

The signaling sequence in a type 2 membrane protein is located inside the membrane.

 

These sequences usually have methionine as the terminal amino acid.

 

Transmembrane proteins are integral proteins that span across the plasma/ endoplasmic reticulum (ER) membrane. They are classified into types 1 to 4. –

 

Type 1 membrane proteins have a cleavable N-terminal signal sequence outside the cell, a transmembrane sequence that is usually situated close to the C-terminus and the C-terminus facing inside the cell, e.g., low-density lipoprotein receptor.

 

Type 2 membrane proteins have the N-terminal towards the cytosol and the C-terminal towards the exterior, e.g., transferrin receptor.

 

Type 3 membrane proteins are identical to type 1 but have a shorter N terminal, e.g., cytochrome P450 enzyme complexes.

 

Type 4 membrane proteins consist of 7 alpha helices traversing the membrane, e.g., glucose transporters and G-protein-coupled receptors.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. At the C-terminal: This is incorrect because the signaling sequence in type 2 membrane proteins is not located at the C-terminal.

 

Option C. At the N-terminal: This is incorrect as well. In type 2 membrane proteins, the N-terminal is facing the cytoplasm, but the signaling sequence itself is located inside the membrane.

 

Option D. Both inside the membrane and at C-terminal: This is incorrect because the signaling sequence is located specifically inside the membrane, not at the C-terminal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The signaling sequence in type 2 membrane proteins is located inside the membrane, crucial for the proper orientation and insertion of the protein.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with hearing loss that developed shortly after her first pregnancy. Her audiometry report is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Otosclerosis


The clinical scenario describes a patient experiencing hearing loss after pregnancy, and the audiogram indicates conductive hearing loss with a notable Carhart’s notch (a specific dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz). These findings are characteristic of otosclerosis.

 

  • Otosclerosis is caused by abnormal bone growth in the bony otic capsule, specifically around the stapes footplate. This leads to stapes fixation, which prevents proper sound conduction, resulting in bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss and sometimes tinnitus.
  • The condition is often inherited in an autosomal dominant manner and can be influenced by hormonal changes, such as pregnancy or menopause, which exacerbate symptoms.
  • Pathophysiology: The most common type is stapedial otosclerosis, starting in the "fistula ante fenestra" region. An active lesion may be identified by the Schwartze sign, a reddish hue visible through the tympanic membrane.
  • Audiometric Findings: Pure tone audiometry (PTA) shows a loss in air conduction with an air-bone gap, predominantly at lower frequencies, and the presence of Carhart’s notch at 2000 Hz. Tympanometry demonstrates an As type tympanogram, reflecting reduced compliance of the middle ear system.
  • Management: Medical management with sodium fluoride is used during the active phase. The definitive treatment is a stapedectomy or stapedotomy, which involves replacing the stapes with a prosthesis. Carhart’s notch usually resolves after successful surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ototoxicity: Ototoxicity results in sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) and is associated with high-frequency hearing loss, as shown by the SNHL curve on an audiogram. It does not cause conductive hearing loss or Carhart’s notch.

 

Option B. Meniere's Disease: Meniere's disease typically presents with SNHL. The early audiometric pattern shows a rising curve (lower frequencies affected first), which may become flat or falling as higher frequencies become involved over time. Conductive hearing loss and Carhart’s notch are not seen in Meniere's disease.

 

Option D. Noise-Induced Hearing Loss: Noise-induced hearing loss is a type of SNHL characterized by an acoustic dip at 4000 Hz on the audiogram. This pattern affects both air and bone conduction and is not associated with conductive hearing loss or Carhart’s notch.

 

Educational Objective:


Otosclerosis is a common cause of conductive hearing loss that can worsen with hormonal changes, such as pregnancy. It is characterized by the presence of Carhart’s notch at 2000 Hz on audiometry and can be treated definitively with a stapedectomy or stapedotomy.

questions.text: Which vacutainer is commonly used to collect blood samples for serum electrolyte analysis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Green

 

The green-top vacutainer contains heparin (specifically lithium heparin), which is an anticoagulant that prevents blood from clotting while allowing for accurate electrolyte analysis, especially for sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), and chloride (Cl-) levels. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Blue: Incorrect. Blue top vacutainer contains sodium citrate and is used for coagulation studies like PT, aPTT. It would not be appropriate for electrolyte analysis.

 

Option B. Yellow: Incorrect. Yellow top vacutainer is used for bacterial culture and HLA typing. It's not suitable for electrolyte analysis.

 

Option D. Purple: Incorrect. Purple/Lavender top vacutainer contains EDTA and is used for complete blood count (CBC), immunohistochemistry studies and ESR testing using the Westergren method. EDTA can interfere with electrolyte measurements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For serum electrolyte analysis, green-top vacutainers (containing lithium heparin) are the preferred choice as they prevent clotting without interfering with the electrolyte measurement.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a major diagnostic criterion of neuromyelitis Optica? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Focal epilepsy

 

Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) spectrum disorder, also known as Devic's disease, is an autoimmune condition characterized by severe, recurrent episodes of optic neuritis and myelitis. The diagnostic criteria for NMO spectrum disorders include specific clinical syndromes.  

 

Focal epilepsy is not a diagnostic criterion for NMO. While seizures can occur in NMOSD due to brain lesions, focal epilepsy itself is not a major diagnostic feature.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Area postrema syndrome  is major criteria. This is characterized by intractable nausea, vomiting, or hiccups, which is due to lesions in the area postrema of the brainstem.

 

Option B. Acute myelitis is major criteria. Inflammation of the spinal cord, usually longitudinally extensive (spanning three or more vertebral segments).

 

Option D. Optic neuritis is major criteria. This involves inflammation of the optic nerve, leading to vision loss or impairment, often affecting both eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnostic Criteria for Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (NMOSD)

 

Most Common Core Clinical criteria:

 

  1. Longitudinal extensive transverse myelitis (acute myelitis)
  2. Optic neuritis, often bilateral
  3. Area postrema syndrome

 

Less Common Clinical Criteria:

 

  1. Acute brainstem syndrome
  2. Acute diencephalic syndrome, which can manifest as symptomatic narcolepsy
  3. Symptomatic cerebral syndrome (symptomatic cerebral lesions)

 

Some patients with NMOSD may have anti-NMO IgG antibody positivity, also known as anti-aquaporin 4 antibody (AQP4-IgG).

questions.text: Nadas criteria include all of the following except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Raised Trop T level

 

Nadas criteria, proposed by Hungarian cardiologist Dr. Alexander Nadas in the 1950s–60s, are used for diagnosing congenital heart disease. The criteria require at least one major and two minor criteria for diagnosis. Major criteria include systolic murmur grade 3-4/6, diastolic murmur, presence of congestive heart failure, and cyanosis. Minor criteria include grade 2/6 systolic murmur, abnormal S2, abnormal chest X-ray, abnormal ECG, and abnormal blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nadas criteria are used for diagnosing congenital heart disease, which includes both major criteria (systolic murmur grade 3-4/6, diastolic murmur, CCF, cyanosis) and minor criteria (grade 2/6 systolic murmur, abnormal S2, abnormal X-ray, abnormal ECG, abnormal BP).

questions.text: A person undergoing Anti PD1 immunotherapy (Nivolumab) presents with itching, eczema, and hives-like rashes. Upon histopathological analysis, a blister beneath the outer skin layer is observed. The direct immunofluorescence assessment of the affected areas indicates the presence of Linear C3 and IgG along the basement membrane. What is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bullous pemphigoid

 

BULLOUS PEMPHIGOID

 

  • Immunobullous disease with a sub epidermal split
  • IgG is the autoantibody deposited
  • Target protein: Hemi desmosomes
  • Target antigens: BPAG 2 > 1
  • No acantholysis
    • Clinical Features: Involves primary lesions (Tense pruritic bullae on Erythematous skin or normal skin) and secondary lesions (Itchy Bullae → Erosions due to scratching).
    • Sites: Trunk, abdomen, flexural aspects of extremities, 10-30% of patients have oral erosions.

 

 

  • Investigation:

 

1. Tzanck smear: Presence of eosinophils and Absence of acantholytic cells.

 

2. Histopathology:

 

 

3. Direct Immunofluorescence: show IgG, C3 linear deposits along Basement Membrane Zone.

 

 

  • Treatment: Topical steroids

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus Vulgaris: Involves intraepidermal blisters and suprabasal acantholysis (separation of skin cells), which are not described in the provided scenario. Direct Immunofluorescence would typically show intercellular deposits, not linear along the basement membrane.

 

Option C. Dermatitis Herpetiformis: Characterized by intensely itchy blisters and associated with gluten sensitivity. Direct Immunofluorescence shows granular IgA deposits at the tips of dermal papillae, not the linear deposition along the basement membrane.

 

Option D. Pemphigus Foliaceous: Presents with superficial (epidermal) blisters that do not affect the deeper layers of the skin. The immunofluorescence pattern would not show the linear deposition along the basement membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bullous Pemphigoid in patients undergoing immunotherapy is critical due to the potential severity of the condition and the need for prompt and effective management to reduce symptoms and prevent complications. Monitoring for new or worsening symptoms in patients on immunotherapy is essential to catch such reactions early.

questions.text: A woman with Grave's disease was taking antithyroid medication throughout her pregnancy. The baby was born with aplasia cutis congenita. Which drug could have caused this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carbimazole 

 

Carbimazole intake during the first trimester of pregnancy is associated with aplasia cutis congenita.

 

Carbimazole and methimazole are linked to teratogenic effects, including:

 

  • Aplasia cutis congenita: Congenital absence of scalp hair and skin, often accompanied by calvarial defects
  • Choanal atresia
  • Tracheoesophageal fistula
  • Fetal goiter

 

The drug of choice for treating hyperthyroidism in the first trimester is propylthiouracil (PTU) because it has a lower risk of teratogenic effects compared to carbimazole or methimazole. However, PTU use is restricted to the first trimester due to the risk of hepatotoxicity and is replaced by methimazole (or carbimazole) in the second and third trimesters.

 

Radioiodine therapy is contraindicated during pregnancy and lactation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Levothyroxine: Incorrect. Levothyroxine is a synthetic thyroid hormone and does not have teratogenic effects.

 

Option C. Methimazole: Partially correct. Methimazole, like carbimazole, can also cause aplasia cutis congenita but was not selected in this context.

 

Option D. Hydrouracil: Incorrect. Hydrouracil is not used for treating hyperthyroidism and is not associated with teratogenic effects like aplasia cutis congenita.

 

Educational Objective:


Carbimazole and methimazole are associated with teratogenic effects, including aplasia cutis congenita, when used in early pregnancy. Propylthiouracil (PTU) is preferred in the first trimester to minimize teratogenic risks but is later replaced to avoid hepatotoxicity.

questions.text: A patient presents to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain. A stool examination was done, and it showed the presence of the organism shown in image A. The body has segments broader than the length. Which of the eggs shown in column B corresponds to this organism? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

The given image shows characteristic features of Hymenolepis nana. This can be identified by its body segments being broader than long.

 

The egg of hymenolepis nana is roughly spherical or ovoid, 30-40 μm size. It has a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryophore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere. The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and 4-8 thread like polar filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore with 6 hooklets as seen in the image. The eggs float in saturated solution of salt and are non-bile stained. They are immediately infective and unable to survive for more than 10 days in external environment.

 

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented in OPD with a swelling in his neck. Given below is the histopathological image. What is the likely diagnosis?  (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medullary carcinoma of thyroid

 

The histopathological image shows Amyloid deposition and nests of polygonal cells, which is suggestive of medullary carcinoma of thyroid. This type of cancer is associated with the presence of amyloid deposits, which can be seen as pinkish extracellular material in the histological sections. These amyloid deposits are derived from calcitonin produced by the neoplastic C-cells (parafollicular cells).

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a neuroendocrine tumor that arises from the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland, which produce calcitonin. The histopathological hallmark of MTC is the presence of amyloid stroma, often stained with Congo red, showing apple-green birefringence under polarized light. Additionally, the tumor cells are often arranged in nests or sheets, with polygonal or spindle-shaped cells.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid: Characterized by the formation of papillae and distinct nuclear features like Orphan-Annie eye nuclei, nuclear grooves, and pseudoinclusions. It typically does not have amyloid deposition.

 

Option C. Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid: Typically shows follicles filled with colloid, and Hurthle cells may be present. This type is also known for hematogenous spread rather than lymphatic spread.

 

Option D. Anaplastic carcinoma of the thyroid: A highly aggressive form of thyroid cancer, characterized by pleomorphic giant cells, spindle cells, and a lack of differentiated features seen in other thyroid carcinomas. It also lacks the amyloid deposits seen in medullary carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A person has suffered from chest trauma resulting in fracture of 2-6th ribs. He is being given pain relief by IV analgesic agents. Which of these blocks will be helpful in pain relief? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thoracic epidural

 

For multiple rib fractures (2nd-6th ribs), thoracic epidural is the most appropriate choice  because:

 

  • It provides effective pain relief by blocking multiple spinal nerve roots at once through a single catheter
  • The epidural can be placed at T4-T5 level to cover the affected dermatomes
  • It allows continuous analgesia through catheter placement
  • It provides stable hemodynamics
  • The epidural catheter can be used for repeated administration of local anesthetic for prolonged pain relief

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical plexus block: Only supplies the neck and shoulder region. Not suitable for rib fractures as it does not cover the thoracic dermatomes.

 

Option B. Supraclavicular block: This is a brachial plexus block that provides anesthesia to the upper limb. It does not cover the thoracic area or ribs.

 

Option D. Lumbar epidural: Provides analgesia below the umbilicus. Not suitable for upper thoracic dermatomes where the fractured ribs are located.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Thoracic epidural is the optimal choice for pain management in multiple rib fractures as it provides effective analgesia through continuous blockade of multiple thoracic dermatomes.

questions.text: In a gunshot case, blackening is noted surrounding a firearm entry wound. Blackening occurs mainly due to: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans.  D. Black smoke particles

 

Blackening around the entry wound is primarily due to the deposition of smoke and soot produced from the burning propellant (gunpowder). This is most notable at close range and creates a dark mark surrounding the entry site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heat Fire Effect : This involves the heat generated by the discharge of a firearm. It can cause singeing of the hair and possibly burning of the skin around the wound, but it does not usually cause blackening.

 

Option B. Muzzle of Firearm Weapon : This refers to the end of the gun barrel. While the muzzle is close to the skin, it may deposit soot and cause burns, but it is not itself a cause of blackening. It's more about proximity effects.

 

Option C. Unburnt Gunpowder Particles : When a gun is fired, unburnt particles of gunpowder can exit the muzzle along with the bullet. These particles can cause stippling or tattooing around the wound, which is not the same as blackening but related to small abrasions on the skin.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The presence of blackening, soot, and unburnt gunpowder at a gunshot entry wound provides crucial information about the distance and angle of the shot.

questions.text: A child presents to you with itchy lesions on the scalp with hair loss as shown in the image below. What would be the next best step? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) KOH mount

 

  • The image shows itchy lesions on the scalp with hair loss which is suggestive of a fungal infection, commonly tinea capitis.
  • The next best step in confirming the diagnosis would be to do a KOH mount.
  • The potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation is used to visualize fungal elements in skin, hair, and nail samples.
  • When applied, KOH dissolves the keratin in the skin, hair, and nails, leaving only fungal cells intact, which can then be visualized under the microscope.

 

Tinea capitis variants:

 

 

  • Ectothrix - Spores & fungus present outside the hair shaft.
  • Endothrix - Spores & fungi present inside the hair shaft.

 

 

 

Kerion:

 

  • Presents in Children with boggy swelling, easily pluckable hair, with regional lymphadenopathy.
  • It is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis.
  • The most common causative organisms of kerion are Zoophilic dermatophytes, T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes. In severe cases, there may be pus along with sinus formation.

 

 

Fig: Lesion: Boggy indurated scalp swelling

 

  • Investigation: 10% KOH mount
  • Treatment: DOC overall and for Microsporum is Griseofulvin

 

Note: DOC for Trichophyton is Terbinafine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Slit skin smear (SSS):

 

  • This is a procedure mainly used for diagnosing leprosy.
  • It involves taking a smear from the skin, usually from the earlobe, to look for acid-fast bacilli.
  • It is not appropriate in this case where fungal infection is suspected.

 

Option C. Gram staining:

 

  • This is a microbiological staining technique that is used to differentiate bacterial species into two large groups based on the chemical and physical properties of their cell walls.
  • It's not the first line of investigation for suspected fungal infections.

 

Option D. Biopsy:

 

  • While a biopsy can be used to diagnose various skin conditions, it is invasive and not the first line of investigation for a suspected fungal infection.
  • A KOH mount is a much simpler and direct test to confirm the presence of fungus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For itchy lesions on the scalp with hair loss suggestive of tinea capitis, a KOH mount is the preferred initial test to visualize fungal elements.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.38, 32.40

choices.text: Open wound with fracture, with wound <1 cm
Open wound with fracture, 1 to 10 cm wound size, but mild soft tissue injury
Open wound >10 cm, though soft tissue coverage not required
Open wound > 10 cm, with extensive injury requiring soft tissue coverage

questions.text: A patient with open wound, with fracture of both bones of right lower limb came to the emergency. The doctor labelled the injury as type 3B according to Gustilo-Anderson Classification. Which of the following would represent the injury? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Open wound > 10 cm, with extensive injury requiring soft tissue coverage

 

GUSTILO AND ANDERSON CLASSIFICATION FOR OPEN FRACTURE

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open wound with fracture, with wound <1 cm. This is the description of Type I of open fracture where the wound is clean and of <1cm length.  

 

Option B. Open wound with fracture, 1 to 10 cm wound size, but mild soft tissue injury. This is the description of Type II of open fracture where the wound length is >1cm with mild soft tissue damage or skin flap or avulsion.

 

Option C. Open wound >10 cm, though soft tissue coverage not required. This is the description of Type IIIA of the open fracture where there is an adequate periosteal coverage present.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Type IIIB of the open fracture is the open wound with significant periosteal stripping.
  • It requires secondary bone coverage and procedures like skin grafting or flap.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used for induction of anesthesia, maintenance and can be safely used in endotracheal intubation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sevoflurane

 

Explanation:

 

Sevoflurane is a versatile inhalation anesthetic that can be used for both the induction and maintenance of anesthesia. Its sweet smell makes it suitable for inhalational induction, especially in pediatric patients and others who might find pungent agents unpleasant. Sevoflurane also provides a smooth transition for endotracheal intubation due to its bronchodilatory effects and stable hemodynamic profile. Additionally, its low blood-gas solubility coefficient allows for rapid induction and emergence from anesthesia, which is beneficial in a surgical setting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Halothane: While Halothane can be used for induction and maintenance of anesthesia, it has a higher risk of hepatotoxicity and arrhythmias. It is also less commonly used in modern practice compared to Sevoflurane.

 

Option B. Desflurane: Desflurane is typically used for maintenance rather than induction due to its pungent odor and tendency to cause airway irritation. It also requires a special heated vaporizer due to its high vapor pressure.

 

Option D. Isoflurane: Isoflurane is primarily used for maintenance of anesthesia rather than induction due to its pungent smell and potential to cause airway irritation. It is less suitable for inhalational induction compared to Sevoflurane.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Sevoflurane is an ideal agent for both the induction and maintenance of anesthesia and is safe for use during endotracheal intubation due to its favorable properties.

choices.text: Basal lamina lining the serous acini
Presence of serous acini with acidophilic tip

questions.text: Which of the following features differentiates the exocrine pancreas from the parotid gland? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Absence of striated duct

 

Absence of striated duct in exocrine pancreas differentiates it from the parotid gland.

 

The exocrine pancreas is comprised entirely of serous acini. Therefore, its general structure is similar to that of the parotid gland, but the two are easily distinguished by:

 

  1. The parotid gland has striated and intercalated intralobular ducts, whereas the pancreas has only the intercalated type.
  2. The excretory ducts of the parotid gland are striated columnar, whereas the excretory duct of the pancreas is a simple columnar.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Basal lamina lining the serous acini: Both exocrine pancreas and parotid gland have serous acini that are lined by a basal lamina. Basal lamina is a thin extracellular matrix layer that underlies epithelial tissues and surrounds the cells in muscles, fat, and Schwann cells. So, this feature does not differentiate the two.

 

Option C. Presence of serous acini with acidophilic tip: Both the exocrine pancreas and the parotid gland have serous acini. In the pancreas, these acinar cells have an acidophilic (eosinophilic) cytoplasm because they contain zymogen granules, which are precursors of digestive enzymes. The parotid gland is purely serous, and its acinar cells also have zymogen granules. Thus, this feature does not uniquely differentiate the two glands.

 

Option D. Presence of apical acinar villi: While the exocrine pancreas has acinar cells with a fine, microvillous border at the apical side (facing the lumen) to increase the secretory surface, this is not a feature that starkly contrasts with the parotid gland. Acinar cells in the parotid gland also have secretory granules toward their apical side.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Striated ducts are a characteristic feature of salivary glands, including the parotid gland. These ducts have basal infoldings associated with mitochondria, which gives them their "striated" appearance. They play a role in modifying the primary saliva produced by the acinar cells. The exocrine pancreas does not possess striated ducts. Instead, it has intercalated ducts that connect the acinar cells to the larger duct system. This feature, therefore, differentiates the exocrine pancreas from the parotid gland.

questions.text: A patient presents in the OPD complaining of unable to evert the ankle. The following deformity is seen. Which of the following gait is present?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stepping gait

 

  • The image shown in the question is of high-stepping gait, where the foot drops due to common peroneal nerve injury and while walking, the foot slaps on the ground.

 

COMMON PERONEAL NERVE INJURY

 

  • The common peroneal nerve is one of the two major branches of the sciatic nerve.
  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates the lateral compartment of the leg, and the deep peroneal nerve innervates the anterior compartment of the leg and the dorsum of the foot.
  • These two nerves are essential in the eversion of the foot and dorsiflexion of the foot, respectively.
  • The innervation of the superficial peroneal nerve are:
    • Motor:
      • Peroneus longus
      • Peroneus brevis
    • Sensory: Anterolateral leg
  • Deep peroneal nerve innervation are:
    • Motor:
      • Tibialis anterior
      • Extensor hallucis longus
      • Extensor digitorum longus
      • Peroneus tertius
    • Sensory: First dorsal webspace
  • The nerve is most vulnerable to injury as it passes around the fibular neck.
  • The most common presentation of a common peroneal nerve injury is a weakness of ankle dorsiflexion and the classic resultant foot drop while ambulating. 
  • Foot drop can develop acutely or over days to weeks, depending on the etiology. It can also be complete or partial in severity.
  • There may also be accompanying numbness or paresthesia present along the lateral leg, dorsal foot, and/or the first toe webspace.
  • Pain may also be present in traumatic cases but is not always present.
  • A patient with weakened or paralyzed dorsiflexors may ambulate with a high steppage gait to prevent dragging of toes on the ground.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Waddling gait. Weakness of the hip girdle and upper thigh muscles, like in myopathies, leads to an instability of the pelvis on standing and walking. If the muscles extending the hip joint are affected, the posture of the hip joint becomes flexed and lumbar lordosis increases. The patients have difficulty in standing up from a sitting position. Due to weakness in the gluteus medius muscle, the hip on the side of the swinging leg drops with each step (referred to as Trendelenburg sign). The gait appears waddling. The patients frequently attempt to counteract the dropping of the hip on the swinging side by bending the trunk towards the side which is in the stance phase. This waddling gait pattern can also be caused when the origin and the insertion site of the gluteus medius muscle are closer to each other than normal, for instance due to a posttraumatic elevation of the trochanter or pseudarthrosis of the femoral neck. 

 

 

Option C. Circumduction gait. Also called as Hemiplegic gait, circumduction gait is most commonly seen in stroke. The patient stands with unilateral weakness on the affected side with arm flexed, adducted and internally rotated. Leg on the same side is in extension with plantar flexion of the foot and toes. While walking, the patient hold their arm to one side and drags the affected leg in semi-circle or circumduction due to weakness of the distal muscles (foot drop) and extensor hypertonia in the lower limb.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image shown in the question is the high stepping gait, seen in the common peroneal nerve injury. This gait is present due to foot drop or weakness of the foot dorsiflexors.

choices.text: Sexual assault done by police officer

questions.text: According to POCSO, aggravated sexual assault includes: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sexual assault done by police officer

 

An offence is treated as ‘aggravated’ when committed by a person in a position of trust or authority of child, such as a member of security forces, police officer, public servant, etc.

 

Other options

 

Option B) Threatening: it comes under sexual harassment in POCSO and not under aggravated sexual assault.

 

Option C) Gang penetrative sexual assault comes under aggravated penetrative sexual assault and not under aggravated sexual assault. Therefore, it cannot be correct in this case.

 

Option D) All of the above: since Option A and Option B are incorrect, it cannot be the answer.

 

Educational objective

 

POCSO

 

The POCSO act defines a child as any person below eighteen years of age. It defines various forms of sexual offenses which include:

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Sexual harassment - Threatening
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Sexual assault - Any act with sexual intent that involves physical contact without penetration.
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Aggravated sexual assault - Similar to sexual assault along with the criteria explained under the term aggravated
  4. ﻿﻿﻿Penetrative sexual assault - An act with sexual intent that involves physical penetration of the penis or any object into the vagina, mouth, urethra, or anus.
  5. ﻿﻿﻿Aggravated penetrative sexual assault - Similar to penetrative sexual assault along with the criteria explained under the term aggravated
  6. ﻿﻿﻿Pornography

 

When it comes to aggravated sexual assault, the crime must involve certain aggravating factors. For example: 

 

  • By a person in a position of the authority such as a police officer, relative, doctor
  • In the course of communal violence
  • On mentally & physically disabled
  • Gang sexual assault
  • Using deadly weapons
  • Causing grievous hurt

choices.text: Screening tests define risk of passing genetic disorder
Screening tests are more accurate than diagnostic tests

questions.text: A genetic counsellor is discussing various types of genetic tests with a couple planning for a child. Which of the following statements accurately describes genetic screening? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Screening tests define risk of passing genetic disorder

 

Genetic screening/testing

 

  • Genetic testing is a type of medical test that identifies changes in genes, chromosomes, or proteins. 
  • It is a process to analyse blood or skin for the systematic search for persons with a particular genotype in a defined population (usually invasive procedures)
  • In order to locate this faulty gene, scientists search for variations in larger pieces of DNA called "markers", latter are found nearby the DNA and become the basis of genetic screening
  • The results of a genetic test can confirm or rule out a suspected genetic condition or help determine a person's chance of developing or passing on a genetic. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Screening tests are more accurate than diagnostic tests: Incorrect. Screening tests assess risk and are not as definitive as diagnostic tests, which provide a precise diagnosis.

 

Option C. Screening requires genetic mapping: Incorrect. Genetic screening does not necessarily involve genetic mapping, which is a detailed analysis of the entire genome.

 

Option D. Involve invasive procedures: Incorrect. Screening tests can often be performed using non-invasive methods such as blood or saliva samples, although some genetic tests may require invasive procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Genetic screening tests are used to define the risk of passing on a genetic disorder and can help determine the likelihood of developing a genetic condition.
  • They are not as definitive as diagnostic tests and do not necessarily involve invasive procedures or genetic mapping.

questions.text: The components of qSOFA score include all except: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased heart rate

 

Quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (qSOFA) scoring system:

 

Other Options:

 

It uses three criteria, assigning one point each for:

 

Option A. Altered mental status

 

Option B. Low blood pressure (SBP < 100 mmHg)
