Option C. High respiratory rate (>22 breaths per min)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequential organ failure assessment score (SOFA score), previously known as the sepsis-related organ failure assessment score, is used to track a person's status during the stay in an intensive care unit (ICU) to determine the extent of a person's organ function or rate of failure.

 

The score is based on six different scores, one each for the respiratory, cardiovascular, hepatic, coagulation, renal and neurological systems.

 

The Quick SOFA Score (quickSOFA or qSOFA) was introduced by the Sepsis-3 group in February 2016 as a simplified version of the SOFA Score as an initial way to identify patients at high risk for poor outcome with an infection.

 

The score ranges from 0 to 3 points. The presence of 2 or more qSOFA points near the onset of infection was associated with a greater risk of death or prolonged intensive care unit stay.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of the image shown below?(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Coxa vara

 

  • Coxa vara is a term used to describe a reduced angle between the neck and shaft of the femur.
  • It may be congenital/acquired (growth anomaly at upper femoral epiphysis) or acquired (secondary to various other pathologies).
  • The normal femoral neck shaft angle is 160° at birth, decreasing to 135 degrees in adult life. An angle of <120 degrees is called coxa vara.

 

 

  • This is coxa vara resulting from some unknown growth anomaly at the upper femoral epiphysis.
  • It is noticed as a painless limp in a child who has just started walking.
  • In severe cases, shortening of the leg may be obvious.
  • On examination, abduction and internal rotation of the hip are limited and the leg is short.
  • X-rays will show a reduction in neck-shaft angle.
  • The epiphyseal plate may be too vertical.
  • There may be a separate triangle of bone in the inferior portion of the metaphysis, called Fairbank’s triangle.

 

 

  • Treatment: Subtrochanteric corrective osteotomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coxa magna. Coxa magna is the asymmetrical, circumferential enlargement and deformation of the femoral head and neck. It is seen in Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, transient synovitis of the hip, developmental dysplasia of the hip, trauma, septic arthritis/osteomyelitis, juvenile rheumatoid arthritis, chronic slipped capital femoral epiphysis.

 

 

Option B. Coxa valga. Coxa valga is a deformity of the hip where there is an increased angle between the femoral neck and femoral shaft. It is often associated with shallow acetabular angles and femoral head subluxation. Bilateral coxa valga can be seen in cerebral palsy, turner syndrome. Unilateral occurs due to trauma causing growth plate arrest. Angle more than 140° is considered as coxa valga.

 

 

 

Option D. Coxa Saltans. It is a condition characterized by a snapping sensation in the hip that comprises of 3 entities: external snapping hip (caused by iliotibial tract sliding over greater trochanter), internal snapping hip (caused by iliopsoas tendon sliding over femoral head, iliopectineal ridge, lesser trochanter, and iliopsoas bursa), and intra-articular snapping hip (caused by loose body in hip/labral tears). It is common in athletes and dancers in their teens or twenties. X-ray usually appears normal. MRI may show inflamed bursa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows coxa vara i.e., reduced angle between the neck and shaft of the femur.

questions.text: A child presented with bilateral proptosis. From the peripheral smear, he was suspected to have chloroma. What is the next investigation of choice? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bone marrow examination

 

The next investigation of choice, in a child suspected to have a chloroma, is a bone marrow biopsy.

 

Chloroma or granulocytic sarcoma is an extramedullary manifestation that occurs in 2% to 14% of patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML). It is a localised tumour forming mass occurring in the skin or orbit due to local infiltration of the tissues by leukemic cells. The tumour is greenish in appearance due to the presence of myeloperoxidase.

 

Frequent sites of involvement are the skin, lymph nodes, gastrointestinal tract, bone, soft tissue, testis, and peritoneum. Isolated orbital involvement of myeloid sarcoma is rare. Proptosis is the most common presentation. Other symptoms include lacrimal swelling, conjunctival mass lesion, retinal hemorrhages, ptosis, dystopia. Decreased visual acuity and ocular movement restriction have also been reported.

 

The diagnosis of AML is made by a combination of routine blood picture and bone marrow examination, coupled with cytochemical stains and other special laboratory investigations.

 

The diagnosis of AML is based on the presence of at least 20% myeloid blasts in the bone marrow.

 

Although myeloid sarcomas are radiosensitive, they are managed with systemic chemotherapy in most cases, even in the absence of bone marrow involvement. Surgery and/or radiation therapy may be indicated for symptomatic lesions or tumors causing local organ dysfunction or obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Platelet count: While important in assessing overall hematologic status, platelet count alone is not sufficient to diagnose chloroma or AML.

 

Option B. WBC count: Similarly, WBC count is part of the complete blood count but does not provide the definitive diagnosis needed in this case.

 

Option C. Flow cytometry: This test can help classify leukemia subtypes by analyzing cell surface markers but is typically performed after a bone marrow examination to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For suspected chloroma in the context of AML, a bone marrow examination is the critical next step to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1150-1154

questions.text: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is most useful in which of the following gynecological malignancies? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carcinoma vulva

 

Sentinel lymph node biopsy is particularly useful in the management of vulval carcinomas among gynecological malignancies. The technique helps in determining the extent of lymph node involvement and thereby reduces unnecessary lymph node dissections and their associated complications, such as lymphedema. Sentinel lymph node biopsy can effectively identify the first lymph node (sentinel node) that drains the primary tumor, which is likely to be the first site of metastasis.

 

  • Lymphatic Mapping and Sentinel Node Biopsy:
    • Intraoperative Injection: Intradermal injection of blue dye around the tumor to map lymphatic drainage.
    • Radioactive Tracer: Labeling tissues with a radioactive tracer and localizing with a hand-held detector.
    • Lymphoscintigraphy: This imaging technique has a 100% detection rate for sentinel lymph nodes.
  • Utility in Other Malignancies:
    • Breast carcinoma
    • Penile carcinoma
    • Malignant melanoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carcinoma vagina: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is less commonly used in vaginal cancer compared to vulvar cancer.

 

Option C. Carcinoma cervix: While sentinel lymph node biopsy can be used, it is more established and routinely applied in vulvar cancer.

 

Option D. Carcinoma endometrium: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is also useful but not as prominently used as in vulvar carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sentinel lymph node biopsy is most useful in vulvar carcinoma among gynecological malignancies to reduce unnecessary lymph node dissection and its complications.

 

Ref: Page no 608, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: 2, 4, and 5
1, 2, and 3
1, 3, and 4

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is correct regarding Peutz-Jeghers syndrome? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. Arborizing pattern of smooth muscle
  2. Loss of heterozygosity in the STK11 gene
  3. Multiple Gl polyps
  4. Autosomal recessive
  5. Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium is seen
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, and 3

 

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant, hereditary disorder.

 

Characterized by

 

  • Multiple intestinal hamartomatous polyps having an arborizing pattern of smooth muscle.
  • Mucocutaneous dark blue to brown melanin pigmentation, which is particularly evident on the face, buccal mucosa, hands, feet, perianal and genital regions

 

 

Germline heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the STK11 gene are present in approximately half of individuals with familial Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

 

Presents at a median age of 11 years.

 

The hamartomatous polyps seen in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome are characterized by a branching network of smooth muscle fibers continuous with the muscularis mucosa that supports the glandular epithelium of the polyp.

 

 

Complications:

 

  • Intussusception, which is occasionally fatal.
  • Markedly increased risk of many malignant conditions. Lifetime risk is approximately 40% and regular surveillance is recommended from a very young age for sex cord tumors of the testes.
  • During later life, there is a risk for gastric and small intestinal cancers, and subsequently for colon, pancreatic (100%), breast, lung, ovarian, and uterine cancers.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Autosomal recessive (4): Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is not autosomal recessive; it is autosomal dominant.
  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (5): This is a feature associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), not Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is characterized by an arborizing pattern of smooth muscle, loss of heterozygosity in the STK11 gene, and multiple GI polyps, and it is autosomal dominant.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1557

questions.text: Cells with prolific smooth endoplasmic reticulum secrete _______:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Steroid hormones

 

Cells with prolific smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER) secrete steroid hormones. The endoplasmic reticulum is an organelle that contains a complex network of tubules in the cytoplasm of cells. There are two types of endoplasmic reticulum:

 

  1. Rough Endoplasmic Reticulum (RER): Ribosomes are attached to the cytoplasmic side of the RER. The primary function of RER is protein synthesis, and it aids in the folding of polypeptide chains with the formation of disulfide bonds.
  2. Smooth Endoplasmic Reticulum (SER): Ribosomes are absent in the SER. This structure is involved in steroid synthesis, particularly in cells that secrete steroid hormones such as adrenal cortical cells and gonadal cells. The SER is also responsible for detoxification processes within cells.

 

In steroid-secreting cells, SER plays a crucial role in hormone production. The synthesized hormones are lipid-soluble and can easily diffuse through cell membranes.

 

Additionally, a related organelle, sarcoplasmic reticulum, is a modified endoplasmic reticulum in muscle cells, playing a vital role in calcium storage and release, which is essential for muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Eicosanoid hormones: Eicosanoids are derived from arachidonic acid and are synthesized by enzymes present in the cytoplasm rather than in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum. They do not involve the SER for their production.

 

Option C. Amine hormones: Amine hormones like adrenaline or noradrenaline are synthesized from amino acids, typically in the cytoplasm and stored in secretory granules. Their synthesis does not involve the smooth endoplasmic reticulum.

 

Option D. Peptide hormones: Peptide hormones are synthesized in the rough endoplasmic reticulum, where ribosomes play an active role in translating mRNA into proteins. These hormones do not require the SER for synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cells with abundant smooth endoplasmic reticulum are specialized for the synthesis of steroid hormones, playing a key role in detoxification and lipid metabolism processes in various cells.

choices.text: Droplet digital PCR

questions.text: Best method for detection of mutations with low allele frequency is? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Droplet digital PCR

 

Option A. Droplet digital PCR : Digital Droplet PCR (ddPCR) is known as the third generation of quantitative PCR and is the Best method for detection of mutation with low allele frequency.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization (FISH): FISH is a cytogenetic technique that uses fluorescent probes to bind to specific DNA sequences. While it is valuable for detecting chromosomal abnormalities, it may not be as sensitive as ddPCR for detecting mutations at low allele frequencies.

 

Option C. Nested PCR: Nested PCR involves two rounds of PCR amplification, with the second round using primers nested within the product of the first round. While it can increase sensitivity, it may not be as quantitative or precise as ddPCR.

 

Option D. Sanger Sequencing: Sanger sequencing is a traditional DNA sequencing method. While it is highly accurate, it may not be as sensitive as ddPCR for detecting low-frequency mutations. It is more suitable for identifying mutations present at higher allele frequencies.

 

Educational objective:

 

Droplet Digital PCR (ddPCR)

 

Principle: Droplet digital PCR is a highly sensitive and quantitative method for detecting and quantifying nucleic acids. It partitions the PCR reaction into thousands of droplets, and each droplet serves as an individual reaction chamber.

 

Advantages: It allows for absolute quantification of DNA with high precision and sensitivity. It is particularly effective in detecting mutations present at low allele frequencies.

 

Application: ddPCR is widely used for detecting rare mutations, monitoring minimal residual disease, and assessing low-abundance targets in various samples.

questions.text: Which of the following options is incorrectly matched? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cystocele - Colposuspension

 

Anterior colporrhaphy is performed for cystocele.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

For cystocele, the appropriate surgical management is anterior colporrhaphy, not colposuspension.

questions.text: A 47-year-old renal transplant patient presented with watery diarrhea. Stool examination revealed oval cysts 30 x 15 microns as shown in the image below. Which among the following is the causative organism:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isospora

 

In this case, the patient is a renal transplant recipient, indicating an immunocompromised state due to immunosuppressive drugs. Immunocompromised patients are more susceptible to infections, including parasitic infections causing diarrhea.

 

The stool examination revealed oval cysts measuring 30 x 15 microns, which were acid-fast positive. These characteristics are crucial in identifying the parasite:

 

  1. Immunocompromised State: This condition makes the patient more prone to infections by opportunistic parasites.
  2. Acid-Fast Positive Cysts: This staining characteristic is seen in certain parasitic cysts.
  3. Size and Shape of Cysts: The cysts are oval and measure 30 x 15 microns.

 

Based on the provided images and reference notes, Isospora belli (now known as Cystoisospora belli) is the parasite that fits these criteria. Isospora cysts are known to be oval in shape and measure approximately 20 to 30 microns in length, consistent with the 30 x 15 microns cysts described in the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryptosporidium: Cryptosporidium cysts are round, not oval, and are much smaller (4 to 6 microns). They do not fit the size and shape described in this case.

 

Option C. Cyclospora: Cyclospora cysts are also round and measure approximately 8 to 10 microns, which do not match the size and shape given in the question.

 

Option D. Microsporidia: Microsporidia produce very small spores (1 to 2 microns) and are not typically described as having 30 x 15 microns cysts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isospora belli (Cystoisospora belli) causes watery diarrhea in immunocompromised patients and is identified by its oval cysts measuring approximately 20 to 30 microns, which are acid-fast positive.

choices.text: Reassure and advice regular follow up once in 6 months
Confirm USG findings by ordering CT scan
Do an exploratory laparoscopy to visualize the nature of cyst
Do CA-125 levels, if normal advise regular check up

questions.text: A 62-year-old female with history of ovarian carcinoma in the mother achieved menopause with smooth transition. She is on hormone replacement therapy. She developed abdominal pain. On examination, a right adnexal mass was palpable and non-tender. On ultrasound, a 3 X 3 cm smooth cyst in her ovary was noted. What is the next best step? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Do CA-125 levels, if normal advise regular check up

 

Explanation:

 

The next best step in managing a postmenopausal woman with a small (3 x 3 cm) smooth ovarian cyst is to measure CA-125 levels. CA-125 is a tumor marker used to assess the risk of ovarian cancer, especially in postmenopausal women. Given the benign characteristics of the cyst on ultrasound and the small size, the initial step is to evaluate CA-125 levels:

 

  • CA-125 Levels: If the CA-125 levels are normal (less than 35), the patient can be advised to have regular follow-ups.
  • Regular Follow-ups: If CA-125 levels are normal, a transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) should be repeated in 6-12 weeks to monitor the cyst. If the cyst persists but remains benign, yearly TVS is recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reassure and advise regular follow-up once in 6 months: While reassurance is part of the management, initial evaluation with CA-125 is necessary to rule out malignancy before deciding on the follow-up schedule.

 

Option B. Confirm USG findings by ordering a CT scan: A CT scan is not the first-line investigation for a simple cyst with benign features. Initial evaluation with CA-125 is more appropriate.

 

Option C. Do an exploratory laparoscopy to visualize the nature of the cyst: This is invasive and not indicated for a small, benign-appearing cyst without other concerning features.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Simple cysts in the post-menopausal age grp:

 

  • ≤ 1cm: Considered normal
  • ≤ 5 cm: Ca125; if normal, repeat in 6-12 weeks
  • > 6 cm: Surgical evaluation

 

Ref: Page no 217, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: The most common form of arthritis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteoarthritis

 

Osteoarthritis (OA) is the most common form of arthritis, especially affecting individuals older than 75 years, with up to 80% experiencing it. OA is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of cartilage, which leads to pain, stiffness, and reduced mobility in affected joints. It primarily affects weight-bearing joints such as the hips, knees, and spine, but can also involve the hands. Unlike inflammatory arthritis, it is not systemic, and joint involvement tends to be limited to specific areas rather than widespread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis: This is an autoimmune inflammatory arthritis, but it is less common than osteoarthritis. It tends to affect smaller joints like the hands and wrists.

 

Option B. Psoriatic arthritis: This is a type of inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis, and it is far less common compared to osteoarthritis.

 

Option C. Seronegative arthritis: This is a group of inflammatory joint diseases that do not have rheumatoid factor, including ankylosing spondylitis, but it is also much less common than osteoarthritis.

 

Educational Objective:


Osteoarthritis is the most prevalent form of arthritis, primarily affecting older adults. It involves the degeneration of joint cartilage, particularly in weight-bearing joints, and differs from inflammatory forms of arthritis like rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: ERCP is least useful in the diagnosis of: (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acute Pancreatitis without choledocholithiasis

 

  • ERCP is not the best diagnostic option for acute pancreatitis without choledocholithiasis.

 

ERCP is typically not the first-line diagnostic tool for acute pancreatitis unless there is a specific reason to suspect bile duct involvement or gallstones as a cause. It is not routinely used for diagnosing acute pancreatitis without choledocholithiasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recurrent pancreatitis: ERCP can be useful in diagnosing the cause of recurrent pancreatitis, especially if there is a suspicion of gallstones or other biliary problems contributing to the condition like pancreas divisum.

 

Option B. Unexplained jaundice: ERCP is valuable in cases of unexplained jaundice because it can help identify any blockages or abnormalities in the bile ducts or pancreatic ducts that may be causing the jaundice.

 

Option C. Periampullary mass: ERCP can aid in the evaluation of periampullary masses, as it allows visualization and potential tissue sampling from this region, helping in Diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • ERCP stands for Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography, which is used to visualize the pancreatic or biliary tree using a side-viewing endoscope.
  • ERCP can be therapeutic or diagnostic and is the best modality for examining the distal biliary tree.
  • Indications for ERCP include relieving biliary obstruction due to gallstone disease, biliary drainage, biliary stenting for strictures and leakage, tissue sampling of the biliary or pancreatic ductal system, balloon dilation of the duodenal papilla or ductal strictures, sphincterotomy, and sphincter of Oddi manometry.
  • Therapeutic ERCP is most commonly used to alleviate biliary obstruction due to gallstone disease and benign or malignant biliary strictures.
  • ERCP can be used to diagnose pancreatic divisum, which may present with recurrent pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 3-year-old toxic child presents with tachypnea, high-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and developed difficulty in swallowing with drooling of saliva within 4-6 hours of fever. Along with airway management. Which of the following needs to be given? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IV Ceftriaxone

 

The clinical presentation of this 3-year-old child, including tachypnea, high-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, dysphagia, and drooling of saliva, suggests acute epiglottitis, a potentially life-threatening condition. Acute epiglottitis is an emergency that can result in airway obstruction due to severe inflammation of the epiglottis and surrounding structures. The management of acute epiglottitis involves the following key steps:

 

  1. Airway Management: Immediate attention to securing the airway is crucial, often requiring endotracheal intubation or, in severe cases, tracheostomy, to prevent airway obstruction.
  2. Empirical Antibiotic Therapy: IV Ceftriaxone is the antibiotic of choice for empirical treatment in acute epiglottitis. Ceftriaxone covers the most common causative organisms, including Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib), which is the most frequent pathogen responsible for this condition.
  3. Dexamethasone is often used as adjunctive therapy to reduce airway edema.

 

Once the culture and sensitivity results are available, antibiotic therapy may be adjusted according to the identified pathogen. The immediate empirical use of Ceftriaxone is crucial in managing this condition until further microbiological data is obtained.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nebulisation with racemic adrenaline: This treatment is typically indicated in cases of croup (laryngotracheobronchitis), not in acute epiglottitis. Croup presents with a "barking" cough and usually a more gradual onset compared to epiglottitis.

 

Option C. Diphtheria antitoxin: This is used in the treatment of diphtheria, which presents with a characteristic thick gray pseudomembrane in the throat, and is not related to the clinical features described here. Diphtheria can also cause descending paralysis and other systemic symptoms not seen in this case.

 

Option D. Start steroids: Steroids are indicated in the management of croup to reduce airway inflammation but are not the first-line treatment in epiglottitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute epiglottitis is a medical emergency requiring immediate airway management and empirical antibiotic therapy, with IV Ceftriaxone being the treatment of choice.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a child who has asymptomatic lesions on the forearm and shaft of the penis, lesions on the shaft of penis are as shown below? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lichen nitidus

 

The image shows an aggregate of skin colored papules over the shaft of penis of a child which is suggestive of lichen nitidus.

 

  • Lichen nitidus most frequently affects children or young adults.
  • The dorsum of the forearms or penis is where Lichen Nitidus most commonly manifests as tiny pinhead-sized flesh-colored papules. In early lesions, Lichen Nitidus and Lichen planus share a similar histological profile. Mucous membrane involvement is quite rare in lichen nitidus. True Koebner’s phenomenon is evident.
  • Lesions are self-limiting & no treatment is required.

 

 

Above Image depicts lichen nitidus over elbow with True Koebner’s phenomenon seen.

 

  • As both LP and Lichen Nitidus share a similar histological profile in early lesions, they are both regarded as variants of LP.
  • Claw clutching Ball appearance: The Ball is comprised of well circumscribed granulomatous infiltrate of lymphocytes, epithelioid cells & occasional Langhan’s giant cells that are clutched by surrounding hyperplastic rete ridges, giving the overall claw clutching ball appearance.
  • Lesions are typically asymptomatic and infrequently need medical attention.
  • The histology of Lichen Nitidus is shown in the image below, where a well-defined granuloma is surrounded by rete pegs and appears to be claw clutching a ball.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lichen planus: This condition often presents as purplish, flat-topped bumps as shown in the image below, these lesions can be itchy. The lesions can also affect mucosal surfaces forming white lacy / reticulate pattern. The described presentation and the image provided do not align with this diagnosis.

 

 

Option C. Scrofuloderma: It is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis which results from the direct invasion of the tubercle bacillus into the skin from underlying tuberculous foci.

 

  • It typically presents as cold abscesses, ulcers, or nodules as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option D. Scabies: This parasitic infection presents with intense itching.

 

  • The burrows of the mite may be seen on the skin, typically in the interdigital spaces.
  • The lesions in the image do not match the typical appearance of scabies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lichen nitidus is a probable diagnosis in a child with asymptomatic lesions on the forearm and genitalia, especially when the lesions appear as tiny, flesh-colored bumps.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 37 page no 37.3, 37.10, 37.11, 37.39

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition Page no 554

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child with a body weight of 15kg and height of 100cm is admitted with renal failure. His blood urea was 100 mg/dL and serum creatinine was 1 mg/dL. What is the closest calculated eGFR in the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 40 ml/min/1.73 m2 BSA

 

Step-by-Step Calculation

 

Step 1: Identify the appropriate k value

For a 4-year-old child: k = 0.413

 

Step 2: Apply the formula

eGFR = k × Height / Serum Creatinine

 

Step 3: Substitute values

eGFR = 0.413 × 100 / 1

 

Step 4: Calculate

eGFR = 41.3 / 1 = 41.3 ml/min/1.73 m²

 

Step 5: Round to nearest option

41.3 ≈ 40 ml/min/1.73 m² BSA
 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate (eGFR) in pediatric patients can be calculated using the Schwartz formula, which is widely used in clinical practice. The formula takes into account the patient's height and serum creatinine levels, along with a constant value that is adjusted for age and sex.

 

The modified Schwartz formula is most commonly used for this purpose. It is given as:

 

 

 

For children aged 1 to 16 years, the constant k is typically 0.413

 

Given the child's height of 100 cm and serum creatinine of 1 mg/dL:

 

 

 

The closest value provided in the options is 40 ml/min/1.73 m² BSA, which is therefore the correct answer

 

Understand and apply the Schwartz formula for estimating eGFR in pediatric patients based on height and serum creatinine levels.

questions.text: The vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) functions to stabilize the image on the retina during head movement. What is the ratio of eye velocity to head velocity, known as the VOR gain?  (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1

 

The vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) gain is 1, indicating that the eyes move at a compensatory velocity equal to the velocity of the head, but in the opposite direction.

 

The vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) allows for eye movements in the opposite direction of head movement to maintain steady gaze and prevent retinal image slip. Nerves involved are 3, 6 & 8.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct VOR gain is crucial for visual stability. A gain of 1 allows for precise compensation for head movements, ensuring that the visual environment remains stable, which is vital for tasks that involve motion and require steady vision, such as reading while in a moving vehicle or playing sports.

questions.text: A patient comes to the hospital within 3 hours of the onset of chest pain. ECG revealed ST depression in anterior chest leads and T wave inversion. She could be best managed by? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Aspirin with heparin

 

The description of diffuse symmetric TWI without ST elevations is consistent with NSTEMI which is characterized by subtotal platelet-rich thrombosis + distal phasic embolization. NSTEMI treated with DAPT+LMWH followed by CAG for risk stratification

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PCI is treatment of choice for STEMI.

 

Option B. Arrhythmia prophylaxis is not the definitive best management strategy

 

Option C. Thrombolysis/Fibrinolytics have no role in the management of NSTEMI

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/ACS/Chap 277

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient complained of bilateral lower limb numbness. He has a history of low BP and gastrectomy done for gastric cancer a year back. On examination, Romberg test is positive and there is loss of proprioception in both lower limbs. Which of the following deficiency can cause this condition? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

This patient's presentation strongly suggests Vitamin B12 deficiency for several reasons:

 

  1. History of gastrectomy – Loss of stomach leads to loss of intrinsic factor, essential for B12 absorption
  2. Neurological symptoms – Bilateral lower limb numbness
  3. Positive Romberg test and loss of proprioception indicate posterior column involvement, which is characteristic of subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord seen in B12 deficiency
  4. The combination of gastrectomy and neurological symptoms is classic for B12 deficiency

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B6 deficiency: While it can cause peripheral neuropathy, it doesn't typically cause posterior column signs

 

Option C. Thiamine deficiency: Primarily causes Wernicke's encephalopathy and cardiovascular symptoms; doesn't typically present with proprioception loss; more commonly seen in alcoholics

 

Option D. Folic acid deficiency: Primarily causes hematological manifestations; does not cause neurological symptoms like B12 deficiency

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastrectomy leads to B12 deficiency due to loss of intrinsic factor, and B12 deficiency can cause subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, presenting with posterior column signs (proprioception loss and positive Romberg test).

questions.text:
Which of the following are properties of ventricular muscle fibers: (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. All or none law
  2. Length-tension relation
  3. Tetanus
  4. Long refractory period
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, and 4

 

Explanation

 

Ventricular muscle fibers exhibit several unique properties that are crucial for their function:

 

1. All or None Law: This principle states that a single muscle fiber will either contract fully or not at all in response to a stimulus. Ventricular muscle fibers act as a syncytium due to the presence of gap junctions made up of connexin proteins, which allows them to follow the all-or-none law. Thus, this property is true for ventricular muscle fibers.

 

2. Length-Tension Relation: The length-tension relationship in ventricular muscle fibers is a reflection of the Frank-Starling law, which states that the force of contraction of the heart muscle is proportional to its initial length (or end-diastolic volume, EDV). This relationship is crucial for adjusting cardiac output based on the volume of blood returning to the heart. Within physiological limits, an increase in the initial length of the muscle fiber increases the force of contraction.

 

4. Long Refractory Period: Ventricular muscle fibers have a long refractory period due to the extended plateau phase in their action potential. This long refractory period is crucial in preventing tetanus and ensuring that the heart muscle relaxes fully before the next contraction, maintaining efficient pumping action.

 

Other Option:

 

3. Tetanus: Tetanus is a sustained muscle contraction that occurs when the muscle is stimulated at a high frequency. However, due to the long refractory period in ventricular muscle fibers, tetanus is not possible. The plateau phase (phase 2) of the cardiac action potential is prolonged, which ensures that the heart muscle cannot be re-stimulated before the previous contraction is complete. This prevents sustained contractions (tetanus), which would be detrimental to cardiac function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ventricular muscle fibers follow the all-or-none law, have a length-tension relationship (Frank-Starling law), and possess a long refractory period that prevents tetanus.

questions.text: A cotton swab, pus stained, is disposed in which color of BMW management category? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Yellow category

 

  • According to the latest BMW (Biomedical Waste Management) guidelines 2017-2018, biomedical waste is categorized into four main categories based on the type of waste and its disposal method. 
  • The yellow category includes human anatomical waste, animal waste, soiled waste (which includes cotton, gauge pieces, bandages, dressings), discarded medicines, and chemical waste.
  • Cotton swabs that are stained with pus are classified as soiled waste and therefore should be disposed of in the yellow category. 
  • The yellow category waste is typically disposed of through incineration (at 1200°C) or plasma pyrolysis. 
  • In some specific cases, especially at the PHC level, deep burial may also be used for certain types of yellow category waste.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Red category: Incorrect. The red category is meant for solid/contaminated (recyclable) waste including plastic and rubber items such as tubings, catheters, and cannulas. 

 

 

Option C. White category: Incorrect. The white category is specifically designated for waste sharps such as needles, surgical blades, and scalpels.

 

 

Option D. Blue category: Incorrect. The blue category is for glassware, orthopedic metallic body implants, and other items from ENT, dental, cardio-thoracic, and vascular surgery. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cotton swabs stained with pus are classified as soiled waste and should be disposed of in the yellow category of biomedical waste management.

questions.text: Culture medium used for Mycobacterium tuberculosis is? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Lowenstein-Jensen medium

 

  • Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium is the most commonly used culture medium for Mycobacterium tuberculosis. 
  • LJ medium has been used since very old times for the culture of M. tuberculosis.
  • The NTEP (National TB Elimination Program) guidelines also recommend the use of LJ medium as one of the diagnostic methods for tuberculosis along with other methods like ZN staining, LED fluorescence microscopy, automated liquid culture (ALC) systems like BACTEC, and rapid molecular diagnostic tests like CBNAAT. 
  • LJ medium provides solid support for the growth of M. tuberculosis, which typically takes 4-8 weeks due to the slow-growing nature of the bacterium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muller Hinton agar: This is incorrect. Muller Hinton agar is mainly used for antibiotic susceptibility testing of non-fastidious bacteria, particularly for routine susceptibility testing of commonly isolated rapid-growing aerobic or facultative organisms. It is not suitable for culturing M. tuberculosis which requires special media for growth due to its slow-growing and fastidious nature.

 

Option B. Blood agar: This is incorrect. Blood agar is a general-purpose enriched medium used to isolate fastidious organisms and detect hemolytic activity. It contains mammalian blood (usually sheep or horse blood) and is not suitable for the isolation of M. tuberculosis, which requires specialized media.

 

Option C. Sabouraud's agar: This is incorrect. Sabouraud's agar is primarily used for the cultivation of fungi, dermatophytes, and yeasts. It contains peptone, dextrose, and agar with a pH of 5.6, which is favorable for fungal growth but inhibits bacterial growth. It is not suitable for the isolation of M. tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lowenstein-Jensen medium as the traditional solid culture medium used for the isolation and identification of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

choices.text: Hemodynamically unstable patient should not be sent for CT scan
All patients should have chest X-ray PA view only
X-ray of the pelvis is done in primary survey
X-rays in primary survey may also be done in pregnant women

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding imaging in the primary survey of a trauma patient except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) All patients should have chest X-ray PA view only

 

Chest X-ray and X-ray pelvis are taken in AP view in the adjuncts to the primary survey of a trauma patient.

 

This statement is false. Chest X-rays are often a standard part of the primary survey to assess for chest injuries and potential life-threatening conditions like pneumothorax or hemothorax, however AP view is commonly used in the primary survey. PA view requires patient to be standing, which is usually not possible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemodynamically unstable patients should not be sent for CT scans: This statement is true. Hemodynamically unstable patients are in a critical condition, and their immediate management should prioritize stabilizing their condition.

 

Option C. X-ray of the pelvis is done in the primary survey: This statement is true. Pelvic X-rays may be performed if pelvic injury is suspected based on clinical assessment, however they are not universally conducted in all trauma patients during the primary survey, hence considered as “adjuncts”.

 

Option D. X-rays in the primary survey may be done in pregnant women: This statement is generally true. Pregnant trauma patients should undergo imaging as needed during the primary survey to assess for injuries. However, the choice of imaging modalities and the use of shielding techniques should consider the safety of the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The steps in the ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support) include:

 

  • Primary survey and simultaneous resuscitation - in order to identify and treat what is killing the patient
  • Secondary survey - proceeding to identify all other injuries
  • Definitive care - developing a definitive management plan

 

ABCDE of trauma care:

 

  • Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate)
  • Breathing and ventilation assessment (maintain adequate oxygenation)
  • Circulation assessment (control hemorrhage and maintain adequate end-organ perfusion)
  • Disability assessment (perform basic neurologic evaluation)
  • Exposure, with environmental control (undress patient and search everywhere for possible injury, while preventing hypothermia)

 

Adjuncts to the primary survey are-

 

  • Blood - CBC, urea and electrolytes, clotting screen, glucose, toxicology, cross-match
  • ECG, pulse oximetry, ventilatory rate, capnography, ABG analysis
  • Two wide-bore cannulae for intravenous fluids
  • Urinary and gastric catheterization
  • Radiographs of the chest and pelvis are done as a part of the primary survey preferably with a portable x-ray unit. When required, all these x rays must also be done in pregnant women.

 

Other more specialized forms of imaging, such as ultrasound, computerized tomography, angiography, and diagnostic peritoneal lavage, should be considered after the secondary survey and only in a patient stable after initial resuscitation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the least common cause of bipedal edema? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic Venous Insufficiency

 

Chronic venous insufficiency (CVI) typically leads to asymmetric leg swelling, where one leg is more affected than the other. In cases of CVI, the swelling is often unilateral, and if bilateral, it is usually asymmetric. This makes it the least common cause of bipedal (symmetric) edema among the given options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lupus Nephritis: This condition affects the kidneys, leading to fluid retention and typically causing bilateral leg swelling. It is a common cause of symmetric bipedal edema.

 

Option C. Heart Failure: This systemic condition causes the heart to pump blood inefficiently, leading to fluid buildup in the lower extremities and symmetric bipedal edema.

 

Option D. Chronic Liver Disease: This condition results in decreased protein synthesis and portal hypertension, causing fluid retention and symmetric bipedal edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic venous insufficiency typically causes unilateral or asymmetric leg swelling, making it the least common cause of symmetric bipedal edema.

questions.text: In fetal alcohol syndrome, which of the following is not seen? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Macrocephaly

 

Fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) is associated with various structural, behavioral, and developmental anomalies due to prenatal alcohol exposure. One of the key features of FAS is microcephaly, not macrocephaly. High levels of alcohol ingestion during pregnancy can severely impact embryonic and fetal development.

 

The presence of at least one of the following characteristics is indicative of fetal alcohol syndrome:

 

  • Growth restriction: Can occur before and/or after birth.
  • Facial anomalies: These include small palpebral fissures, indistinct or absent philtrum, epicanthic folds, flattened nasal bridge, short length of nose, thin upper lip, low-set and unparallel ears, and retarded midfacial development.
  • CNS dysfunction: Includes microcephaly, mental retardation, and abnormal neurobehavioral development such as attention deficit with hyperactivity.

 

Other features that may be seen in FAS include:

 

  • Incomplete holoprosencephaly: A condition where the forebrain does not completely divide into two hemispheres.
  • Agenesis of the corpus callosum and cerebellar vermis: Developmental anomalies where these brain structures are partially or completely absent.
  • Cardiac anomalies: Such as ventricular septal defect (VSD), atrial septal defect (ASD), and tetralogy of Fallot.

 

Macrocephaly is not seen in fetal alcohol syndrome; instead, microcephaly is characteristic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thinning of corpus callosum: This is a characteristic finding in fetal alcohol syndrome due to developmental anomalies.

 

Option B. Microcephaly: This is commonly seen in fetal alcohol syndrome and is one of the diagnostic features.

 

Option C. Holoprosencephaly: Incomplete holoprosencephaly can be seen in fetal alcohol syndrome as a result of severe midline developmental anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal alcohol syndrome is associated with microcephaly, not macrocephaly.

 

Ref: Page no 397, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a patient who presents with flaccid bullous lesions affecting both the oral cavity and the skin, as shown in the provided image, and exhibits acantholytic cells on Tzanck smear? (AIIMS May 2019
questions.solution:
Ans B) Pemphigus vulgaris

 

Flaccid lesions, mucosal involvement, and the presence of acantholytic cells are suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris.

 

The production of antibodies, specifically those against Desmoglein 3, is seen in Pemphigus vulgaris. Desmoglein 1 antibodies are also occasionally associated. Usually, the antibodies are IgG antibodies. The skin and mucosa's basal and suprabasal layers contain the majority of Desmoglein 3.

 

The patients, therefore, present with flaccid bullae over the skin and due to Desmoglein 3 involvement, mucosal involvement can also be seen. Oral mucosa is commonly affected. Other areas where ulceration can be seen are conjunctiva, nasopharynx, larynx, etc.

 

Cutaneous lesions are more common over the scalp, face, neck, upper chest, and back.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus foliaceus: Autoantibodies are seen against only Desmoglein 1, not against DsG 3, so there is no mucosal involvement in pemphigus foliaceus.

 

Option C. Dermatitis herpetiformis presents with multiple small Papulo-vesicles, which are extremely itchy and it is a subepidermal blistering disorder, so acantholysis will not be seen.

 

Option D. Bullous Pemphigoid presents as Tense bullae, which can have an erythematous base (urticarial wheals) & it is a subepidermal blistering disorder, so acantholysis will not be seen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of flaccid bullous lesions affecting both the oral cavity and the skin, along with the observation of acantholytic cells on a Tzanck smear, is most consistent with a diagnosis of pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 50 Page no 50.1-50.8

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 356

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with Ewing sarcoma with ESWR1 gene mutation. The technique shown in the image was performed to confirm the diagnosis. Identify the technique shown in the image? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fluorescent in situ hybridization

 

The technique shown in the image is FISH demonstrating a positive EWSR1 gene rearrangement, characteristic of Ewing sarcoma.

 

The fused region denoted by Yellow corresponds to a normal intact gene, while a split signal pattern showing separate red and green signals is indicative of EWSR1 gene rearrangement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Karyotyping :

  • Karyotyping is a technique used to examine the number, size, and shape of chromosomes in a cell. While karyotyping can provide information about chromosomal abnormalities, it may not be as specific as FISH in detecting the specific EWSR1 gene translocation associated with Ewing sarcoma.
  • Relevance: Karyotyping is a broader chromosome analysis technique and may not be the primary method for confirming Ewing sarcoma diagnosis.

 

Option C. Immunohistochemistry

  • Immunohistochemistry is a technique used to detect specific proteins in tissue samples. While it can be valuable in characterizing the tumor's protein expression, it may not directly confirm the presence of the EWSR1 gene mutation, which is a genetic abnormality.
  • Relevance: Immunohistochemistry can be used as a complementary technique to assess protein markers associated with Ewing sarcoma, but it may not be the primary method for confirming the genetic mutation.

 

Option D. Sanger's Technique

  •  Sanger sequencing is a method used for DNA sequencing. It is primarily used to determine the nucleotide sequence of DNA but may not be the technique of choice for confirming the specific EWSR1 gene mutation associated with Ewing sarcoma.
  • Relevance: Sanger sequencing is more focused on DNA sequence analysis rather than detecting gene translocations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In situ hybridization is a modified version of DNA–DNA hybridization. If a metaphase spread chromosome preparation is probed with a gene, the location of the gene on a specific chromosome can be identified. The principle may be applied to histology slide also. In the tissue preparation, DNA is denatured, the specific probe tagged with fluorescent labels, incubated, washed and seen under a fluorescent (UV) microscope. The process is named as Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH).

 

Applications of FISH are:

 

  1. Detects subtle microdeletions and rearrangements.
  2. Detects complex translocation
  3. Assessment of gene rearrangements in leukaemia
  4. Determination of amplification of HER2/neu in breast cancer
  5. Diagnosis of various types of lymphomas.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug is associated with increased risk of urinary tract infections? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

 

Dapagliflozin is a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor. SGLT2 inhibitors work by promoting the excretion of glucose through the urine. This increased urinary glucose can create an environment that promotes the growth of bacteria, thereby increasing the risk of urinary tract infections. This class of drugs is well known for its association with UTIs and genital infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that improves insulin sensitivity. It is not associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections. Common side effects include weight gain, edema, and an increased risk of heart failure.

 

Option C. Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. It works by increasing incretin levels, which in turn increase insulin secretion and decrease glucagon secretion. Sitagliptin is not commonly associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections.

 

Option D. Metformin: Metformin is a biguanide that decreases hepatic glucose production and improves insulin sensitivity. It is not associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections. Common side effects of metformin include gastrointestinal disturbances such as diarrhea and abdominal discomfort.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, dapagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections due to its mechanism of increasing glucose excretion in the urine. This patient’s recurrent UTIs could be related to her use of dapagliflozin.

choices.text: Continue the transfusion but do an ECG
Stop the transfusion, wait for the patient to stabilize, and then restart it
Do clerical check and get an ECG

questions.text: A patient with thalassemia has a history of multiple blood transfusions, iron overload, and cardiac arrhythmia. She has now come for blood transfusion and during the process, complains of backache and looks very anxious. What would you do next?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stop the blood transfusion


The patient's complaints of backache and anxiety during a blood transfusion raise suspicion of an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR), which requires immediate action. AHTR is a serious complication that typically occurs due to ABO incompatibility and can develop within the first 24 hours of transfusion. Symptoms of AHTR include hypotension, tachypnea, tachycardia, fever (temperature increase of 1-2°C), chills, chest and back pain, hemoglobinuria, and hemoglobinemia. Severe cases may progress to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), acute renal failure, shock, and even death.

 

Management of AHTR:

 

  1. Stop the transfusion immediately – This is the first and most critical step to prevent further hemolysis.
  2. Collect blood samples – After stopping the transfusion, collect samples from the patient for further testing to confirm the reaction and identify its cause.
  3. Supportive care – Administer vigorous hydration with isotonic saline and use diuretics to maintain urine output, helping to prevent renal damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Continue the transfusion but do an ECG: Continuing the transfusion is inappropriate in the context of suspected AHTR, as it would worsen the reaction.

 

Option C. Stop the transfusion, wait for the patient to stabilize, and then restart it:  Restarting the transfusion after stabilization is unsafe in AHTR, as re-exposure to the incompatible blood could lead to severe complications.

 

Option D. Do clerical check and get an ECG:  Although a clerical check is essential to confirm the transfusion details, the immediate priority in suspected AHTR is to stop the transfusion.

 

Educational Objective:


In cases of suspected acute hemolytic transfusion reaction, the first and most crucial step is to immediately stop the blood transfusion to prevent further complications.

questions.text: The following set of instruments are used for which procedure? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pap smear

 

Explanation:

 

The given set of instruments are commonly used for taking a Pap smear. The instruments include:

 

  • Cusco's bivalved self-retaining speculum: Used to visualize the cervix.
  • Koplin's jar: Used to store the collected sample.
  • Slides to prepare the smear: Used for placing the collected sample.
  • Ayer's spatula and endocervical brush: Used to collect cells from the ectocervix and endocervix, respectively.
  • Fixative containing 95% ethanol: Used to preserve the collected sample on the slides.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hysteroscopy: This procedure involves using a hysteroscope to visualize the inside of the uterine cavity, and the instruments shown are not used for this purpose.

 

Option C. Biopsy: While some of these instruments might be used in a cervical biopsy, the specific combination shown is typically for a Pap smear.

 

Option D. Dilatation and curettage: This procedure involves dilating the cervix and scraping the endometrial lining, which requires different instruments than those shown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The set of instruments shown, including Cusco's speculum, Koplin's jar, slides, Ayer's spatula, endocervical brush, and fixative, are used for performing a Pap smear to collect and preserve cervical cell samples for cytological examination.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 110,111, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition 632, 633

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for scrub typhus during pregnancy and otherwise respectively? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Azithromycin, doxycycline

 

The DOC for scrub typhus is Doxycycline, but it cannot be used during pregnancy as it can lead to bone growth abnormality in the newborn. So, in that case, to treat Scrub Typhus in Pregnancy, we use Azithromycin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chloramphenicol, doxycycline: Chloramphenicol is not the first-line treatment for scrub typhus, and doxycycline is indeed used for non-pregnant individuals, but this pair does not cover the correct alternatives during pregnancy.

 

Option B. Doxycycline, doxycycline: This option does not address the contraindication of doxycycline during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Doxycycline, azithromycin: This reverses the correct pair; azithromycin is used during pregnancy, not doxycycline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The drug of choice for treating scrub typhus in pregnant women is azithromycin, while doxycycline is used for non-pregnant individuals.

questions.text: Handedness is seen at the age of ______. (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3 years

 

Handedness is typically established at the age of 3 years. This refers to a child's preference for using one hand over the other, which usually becomes noticeable around this age. It is a part of the developmental milestones that children go through, and at this age, a child is expected to have a clear preference for either the right or left hand. Trying to change a child’s hand preference after this age may result in frustration or confusion for the child.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 year: At 1 year, children are developing motor skills, such as walking with support or independently. However, their hand preference is not firmly established at this stage, and both hands are typically used interchangeably.

 

Option B. 2 years: By 2 years, children have better motor control and can perform simple tasks, such as making a tower of blocks, but hand preference (handedness) is still not clearly defined or permanent at this stage.

 

Option D. 4 years: Although children can perform more complex tasks by 4 years of age, such as drawing shapes or hopping, their handedness is already established by this time, which typically happens around 3 years of age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Handedness is typically seen and established by the age of 3 years. This is a crucial developmental milestone and should be recognized as part of normal child development.

questions.text: Identify the wrong statement regarding the period of gestation calculation: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period

 

  • Gestational age or period of gestation (POG) refers to the duration of pregnancy calculated from the first day of last menstrual period
  • Calculating the EDD:
    • Normal duration of pregnancy: 280 days (40 weeks)
    • Calculating the EDD: Naegele’s formula. To the LMP (1st day of the last menstrual day)
      • Add 9 months + 7 days
      • Subtract 3 months and add 7 days
      • For IVF Pregnancies: add 38 weeks to the date of the embryo transfer
    • Dating the pregnancy: If discrepancy in dates/ unsure of LMP; the best way to determine the dating is by ULTRASOUND
      • 1st trimester CRL: most accurate (till 14 weeks)
      • BPD in the 2nd trimester

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1st trimester USG is the best assessment: Correct, because the 1st trimester USG provides the most accurate dating method.

 

Option C. In an IVF pregnancy, day of embryo transfer/day of fertilization is needed to calculate POG: Correct, because calculating gestational age in IVF pregnancies relies on the day of embryo transfer or fertilization.

 

Option D. Crown-rump length is the best measure of period of gestation in the first trimester: Correct, because CRL is the best measure for assessing the period of gestation in the first trimester.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gestational age is calculated from the first day of the last menstrual period (LMP), not the last day.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg, Dutta’s 108, 109, textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg127

questions.text: Surgical correction of VSD is performed in an infant. This will help in relieving which of the following features? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Failure to thrive.

 

Surgical correction of a Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) primarily helps in relieving the symptoms of congestive heart failure, which often manifest as failure to thrive in infants. Infants with VSD may experience poor weight gain, difficulty feeding, excessive sweating, irritability, and signs of respiratory distress such as tachypnea and labored breathing. These symptoms arise because the left-to-right shunt created by the VSD increases pulmonary blood flow, leading to pulmonary overcirculation and congestive heart failure. Surgical intervention closes the defect, thereby normalizing blood flow and alleviating the symptoms of heart failure, allowing the infant to grow and thrive normally.

 

The key indications for VSD surgery include:

 

  • Large defects associated with pulmonary hypertension.
  • Qp ratio greater than 2:1 (indicating a significant left-to-right shunt).
  • Supracristal VSD, which carries a risk of aortic valve involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory alkalosis: Respiratory alkalosis is not typically associated with VSD. VSD primarily affects the heart and pulmonary circulation rather than directly causing changes in the acid-base balance.

 

Option C. Arrhythmia: Arrhythmias in infants are usually related to electrolyte imbalances or other cardiac conditions, but not directly to VSD. Surgical correction of VSD is aimed at correcting the structural defect, not managing arrhythmias.

 

Option D. Heart block: Heart block is a conduction issue in the heart and is not a feature directly caused by VSD. VSD surgery does not specifically address heart block.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgical correction of VSD in infants primarily helps relieve congestive heart failure symptoms, particularly failure to thrive, by normalizing pulmonary blood flow.
